title: Why are bond vigilantes holding back their fire?
content: A core tenet of sovereign debt investment is that strong institutions keep down a country’s borrowing costs and vice versa. So then why has the bond market’s response to U.S. President Donald Trump’s ...
resumen: A core tenet of sovereign debt investment is that strong institutions keep down a country’s borrowing costs and vice versa. The bond market’s response to U.S. President Donald Trump’s institutional norm-busting has been tame. Roughly a third of U.S. Treasuries were held in foreign hands as of March. Investors typically lend to sovereign borrowers when the country has institutions in place to protect against the threat of expropriation. If a country’s institutions are weak, or weakening, creditors will significantly increase the sovereign’s borrowing costs to compensate for the rising risk. The classic academic article on this topic was written by Douglas North and Barry Weingast in 1989. The country was able to borrow significantly more after putting in place effective institutions intended to assure investors that parliament could, and would, check the monarch’s temptation to expropriate. Having institutions that can constrain an overreaching sovereign, such as a strong and independent judiciary, central bank and press, do indeed help keep down borrowing costs. Countries that carry the biggest risk premia in debt markets, such as Belarus, Lebanon, and Sudan, are far from models of institutional stability. Since January, Donald Trump’s administration has challenged many domestic institutional norms, long considered key constraining mechanisms on the executive. This has included confrontations with judges, legislators, the central bank, bureaucrats, academics, protesters, law firms and even provisions of the U.S. Constitution itself. The administration has backed out of or undermined numerous international agreements, including the Paris Agreement on climate change and the World Health Organization. The announcement of broad-based “reciprocal tariffs” challenges the foundation of the modern trade system as regulated by the World Trade Organization. We would have expected to see a significant move upward in U.S. Treasury yields. There have been some signs of discontent among bond investors, including after Trump’s "Liberation Day" tariff announcement and following his musings that Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell’s termination “cannot come fast enough.” Jumps of less than 75 basis points in the 10-year Treasury yield seem rather contained. The term premium on the 10-year U.S. Treasury note – a measure of compensation investors demand for holding longer-dated U.S. government debt – hit a 10-year high in May. The risk of a U.S. default remains low. The dollar remains the world’s reserve currency, so the U.S. has more room for fiscal profligacy than most. The $28 trillion U.S. Treasury market remains a key pillar of the global financial architecture. There is already talk of increased debt issuance in Europe offering investors a risk-free alternative. The cost of U.S. borrowing could rise meaningfully.

title: American dominance is not dead, but it is changing — and not for the better
content: Through its numerous statements and decisions, the Trump administration is breaking with the American hegemony that has long structured the international order. The country will emerge weakened.
resumen:
American dominance is changing, and not for the better.

Published: July 2, 2025 1.18pm BST.

Author: Laurent Borzillo, École nationale d'administration publique (ENAP).

Laurent Borzillo is secretary general of the French association Forum de défense et de stratégie. He was awarded the FRQ's PBEEE postdoctoral fellowship (2023-2024) and, in recent years, has been a co-recipient with various colleagues of grants from the French, German (DAAD), and Canadian governments for various projects on the politicization of defense issues, disinformation, elections in Europe, and the transatlantic security architecture.

The Trump administration has been making announcements that upset the established order, including reviving a proposal to purchase Greenland without ruling out military action. American officials have publicly spread pro-Russian narratives and escalated protectionism by introducing tariffs, often announced unilaterally and suddenly, but fluctuate according to the president’s moods.

The U.S. has been the dominant player in the global system in recent decades.

As a researcher at ENAP specializing in international relations theory, I believe that it marks a significant step in the emergence of counter-hegemonic powers and, by extension, that it signals a weakening of American power.

The idea of a U.S. decline has been circulating regularly in academic and strategic circles since the Cold War.

British scholar Susan Strange challenged this “declinist” view, insisting that the true strength of the U.S. lay not just in its economic or military power, but in its central role within major international institutions and strategic alliances.

After the end of the Cold War, French Minister Hubert Védrine declared the U.S. a “hyperpower” for the way it concentrated all the means of global domination.

The debate on the decline of American hegemony has returned with a vengeance, fuelled by the rise of countries such as China, Russia, India, Brazil, Iran and South Africa.

No consensus has emerged within the academic community about the nature of the international system (unipolar, bipolar, or even multipolar).

Political science professors Douglas Lemke of Pennsylvania State University and Suzanne Werner of Emory University have shown this in their work on regional systems.

None of the candidates for counter-hegemony (China, India, Japan or even the European Union) have so far managed to match the U.S. on one key point: its ability to forge strong and lasting alliances and occupy a central position in major international organizations.

This aligns closely with research by Daniel Nexon, professor at Georgetown University, and Thomas Wright, director of the U.S.-Europe Center at the Brookings Institution. They distinguish between two main types of hegemony:

Classical or imperial hegemony is based on coercion, threats and unbalanced bilateral relations. A country with this type of hegemony imposes its preferences without submitting to shared rules.

Liberal hegemony is based on shared and binding institutions, to which even the dominant power agrees to submit in exchange for more stable and legitimate co-operation.

The U.S-led international order since 1945 clearly falls under the second model.

During the Cold War, its hegemony was exercised mainly in the western world. But after the fall of the Soviet bloc, this influence spread globally. The U.S. came to embody a form of institutional hegemony, supported by networks of alliances like NATO and the G7 and multilateral institutions that include the United Nations, the International Monetary Fund and the World Trade Organization.

This made American domination more acceptable, less brutal, and above all more difficult to compete with. Even though the American position was weakened in certain areas, it remained central because it guaranteed stability and predictability that its rivals — including China and Russia, who favoured a more coercive approach — could not offer.

It was precisely this liberal/constitutional model of hegemony that slowed the emergence of real global counterpowers.

Through its numerous statements and decisions, the Trump administration is breaking with the liberal hegemony that has structured the international order for decades.

In its place, a more authoritarian, unilateral stance is emerging, close to what researchers call classic hegemony.

Olivier Schmitt, professor and specialist of alliances at the Royal Danish Defence College, raised the possibility a few months ago of a “Warsawization” of NATO, a scenario in which Washington would transform the organization into a kind of counterpart to the Warsaw Pact, with a rigid and asymmetrical structure based on fear rather than co-operation.

The Trump administration acts as if international relations were a non-iterative game, in the sense of game theory — in other words, a game in which refusing to co-operate is the most winning strategy.

By acting in this way, the U.S. projects the image of an opportunistic and unstable entity whose commitments no longer have lasting value. This change in posture erodes trust and undermines the stabilizing role that the U.S. had once successfully embodied.

Europe and some of its partners are embarking on what looks like a new “western schism,” positioning themselves as a liberal counter-model to Trump’s America.

The conditions are now in place for the emergence of genuine counter-hegemonies. This dynamic will continue even if the Democrats return to power in 2029: the Trumpist interlude will have provided America’s allies with proof that an alliance with the U.S. is only reliable when the White House is Democratic, and that it immediately becomes precarious as soon as a Republican occupies it.

This uncertainty will fuel mistrust and push for the consolidation of counter-hegemonic strategies. Even a partial restoration of the liberal order will probably not be enough to stem the fragmentation of the international system that is already underway.

The Trump administration is only just beginning its term: unless there is a reversal in the midterm elections in November 2026, it will still have considerable margin for manoeuvre until January 2029.

Trump’s second term does not simply mark a shift, but a lasting break. The slogan “Make America Great Again” now seems even more misguided: instead of restoring American power, this policy is accelerating its decline.

title: China braces for US trade deals that aim to shut it out
content: The trade truce between Washington and Beijing may be holding for now, but China is increasingly wary about what’s happening elsewhere: US efforts to forge deals that could isolate Chinese firms from ...
resumen: China is wary of US efforts to forge deals that could isolate Chinese firms from global supply chains. US officials are in talks with major trading partners in Asia and Europe, pushing for new agreements that would include restrictions on Chinese content or secure commitments to counter what Washington sees as China’s unfair trade practices. India is negotiating over rules of origin, with Washington wanting at least 60% of a product’s value added locally to qualify as “Made in India”. Vietnam and others are under pressure to adopt tiered tariff systems, with higher levies for goods that include a large share of Chinese components. Exports from Vietnam to the US that contain the highest proportion of foreign components would be charged at the top end of a range, around 20% or above. The approach mirrors provisions in an existing US trade agreement with Mexico and Canada. China, a larger trade partner than the US for most Asian economies, has warned of consequences if its interests are threatened. Foreign Minister Wang Yi is likely to raise that again on his visit to Europe this week for talks in Brussels, Germany and France. The Ministry of Commerce said in a statement on Saturday, “China firmly opposes any party reaching a deal at the expense of Chinese interests in exchange for so-called tariff reductions” and will “resolutely counter it to safeguard its legitimate rights and interests.” President Donald Trump’s 90-day pause on tariffs ends on July 9. Thailand, Vietnam and South Korea have all put in place measures to stop goods from being rerouted through their countries to the US since Trump’s tariffs were announced in April. South Korean customs announced a crackdown on transshipments. Taiwan President Lai Ching-te also flagged the issue and followed up with new rules requiring all US-bound exports to carry a legal declaration they were made on the island. The US could convince others to impose or tighten export controls on high-tech equipment. Taiwan in June added Huawei Technologies and Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp to its so-called entity list. The EU is China’s largest export destination for electric vehicles, and investment from Chinese firms into the bloc plus the UK hit 10 billion euros ($12 billion) last year, according to recent research from Rhodium Group. European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen recently accused Beijing of “weaponising” rare earths and magnets. Beijing is particularly concerned that the EU might sign up to provisions similar to those in the UK’s deal with the US, which included commitments around supply chain security, export controls and ownership rules in sectors like steel, aluminium and pharmaceuticals. Beijing criticised the agreement in a rare public statement. Brussels and Washington are aiming to reach some form of an agreement before July 9, when Washington is set to impose a 50% tariff on nearly all EU products. European exports to the US are worth more than double the amount to China. China’s weekend statement is “obviously aimed entirely at Brussels”. The long-term risk for Beijing is that these efforts coalesce into a broader shift — not just a US-led campaign to curb Chinese exports, but a reshaping of global trade around “trusted” supply chains, with China increasingly on the outside. President Xi Jinping urged the region to stand together as an “Asian family”, warning against trade fragmentation. China launched anti-dumping probes into European brandy, dairy and pork when the EU imposed tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles last year. It halted Japanese seafood imports in 2023. A spat with Australia in 2020 led to trade restrictions on billions of dollars’ worth of goods. Tu Xinquan, dean of the China Institute for WTO Studies at the University of International Business and Economics in Beijing, said, “If some agreements explicitly list China as a target and show that some countries are cooperating or collaborating with the US to ‘contain China’, then China will definitely respond.”

title: The DOGE Wild Card in Musk’s Feud With Trump
content: Joe Gebbia, a confidant of the technology billionaire and a Tesla director, is also a leader of the federal cost-cutting team. The fight might put him in a bind.
resumen:
The short-lived truce between President Trump and Elon Musk appears over, broken by Musk’s persistent criticism of the Republican domestic policy bill and then the president’s heated response. Trump wrote on Truth Social on Tuesday, “Elon may get more subsidy than any human being in history, by far.” The president added, “Perhaps we should have DOGE take a good, hard, look at this?”

Any move to sic the so-called Department of Government Efficiency, the government cost-cutting initiative that Musk championed, on him could put one man in an increasingly complicated position: Joe Gebbia, the Airbnb co-founder. Gebbia sits on Tesla’s board and is a close friend and confidant of Musk, the Tesla chief. That means Gebbia has a fiduciary duty to the carmaker and its shareholders. Gebbia remains deeply involved with DOGE. He was recruited by Musk himself and stayed after his friend’s departure from government. He is poised to take on a key leadership role on the team, The Times has reported, along with the former Morgan Stanley investment banker Anthony Armstrong, another Musk ally. Any move to deploy DOGE against Tesla could create a conflict for Gebbia. Most of his work at the cost-cutting initiative has focused on digitizing paper-based federal retirement processes. Could he fulfill his duties to Tesla while living up to his government commitment? Gebbia couldn’t be reached for comment. A representative for Robyn Denholm, Tesla’s chair, declined to comment.

Musk has repeatedly hit out at the Republican legislation as fiscally irresponsible, writing on X on Tuesday, “All I’m asking is that we don’t bankrupt America 🤷‍♂️.” He has threatened to form a new political party and to challenge sitting lawmakers who vote in favor of the proposal. That has angered Trump, who has chalked up the outburst to the legislation’s elimination of electric-vehicle subsidies that benefit Tesla. Hence his threat to cut off federal funding to Musk’s business empire, including SpaceX, Starlink and Tesla: “No more Rocket launches, Satellites, or Electric Car Production, and our Country would save a FORTUNE,” the president wrote on Truth Social. Shares in Tesla have already plunged more than 11 percent over the last five trading sessions.

title: The Trump-Deranged ‘Experts’ Were Wrong. Again.
content: Some of the marquee newspapers recently made a series of statements by so-called experts that are absolutely confounded by reality.
resumen:
Victor Davis Hanson for The Daily Signal discusses the failures of "experts" regarding various issues.

The "experts" were wrong about Iran, with initial reports downplaying the damage from strikes on uranium enrichment sites, despite evidence of serious damage from analysts like David Albright and Rafael Mariano Grossi, head of the International Atomic Energy Agency, and Israeli intelligence.

The Left's predictions of a catastrophic war and mass casualties following the strikes on Iran did not materialize.

The "experts" were wrong about the border, as Donald Trump's policies, including self-deportation incentives, led to almost a million people self-deporting, and immigration became a problem of managing those who came under the Biden administration.

The Wall Street Journal's predictions of economic collapse due to tariffs were also incorrect, as the stock market is at a record high, and job creation is good.

Hanson concludes that the criticism of Donald Trump was often based on Trump Derangement Syndrome, which affects judgment and analysis.

title: Mexico peso set to slip after expiry of US tariff hike freeze
content: The rallying Mexican peso is set to slip in the coming months after a temporary freeze on U.S. tariff hikes against other countries expires next week, a Reuters poll showed.
resumen:
El peso mexicano, que ha estado subiendo, se espera que caiga en los próximos meses después de que expire la congelación temporal de los aranceles estadounidenses contra otros países la próxima semana, según una encuesta de Reuters.

El peso está previsto que caiga un 5,5% moderado en los próximos 12 meses, hasta 19,80 por dólar, desde 18,72 el martes, según la estimación mediana de 22 expertos en divisas encuestados entre el 27 de junio y el 2 de julio.

El peso mexicano ha subido un 13,2% en lo que va de año.

Erick Martinez, estratega de tipos de cambio y tipos de interés de Latam en Barclays, dijo: "México no está sujeto a aranceles recíprocos, lo que alivia la presión sobre el peso hasta la fecha límite mundial del 9 de julio".

Alejandro Saldaña, economista jefe de Ve por Mas, dijo que cualquier debilidad debería ser limitada "gracias a la protección del USMCA (acuerdo) por el cual México ha mantenido un trato comercial preferencial en Estados Unidos".

En Brasil, el real probablemente se depreciará un 4% hasta 5,69 por dólar desde 5,46 el lunes en 12 meses.

En Argentina, se prevé que el peso caiga un 17% en un año, hasta 1.465 por dólar.

En lo que va de año, el real brasileño ha ganado un 11,2% y el peso argentino ha perdido un 15,7%.

title: Mexican Peso rally faces reversal as US tariff freeze nears expiry
content: The Mexican peso, one of the best-performing emerging market currencies this year, is expected to fall in the coming months.
resumen: The Mexican peso is expected to weaken by 5.5% in the next 12 months, falling to 19.80 per US dollar from its current level of 18.72, according to a Reuters poll of foreign exchange strategists surveyed between June 27 and July 2. The peso has appreciated 13.2% so far this year. The temporary pause on US tariffs expires on July 9. Mexico is mainly immune to direct tariff retaliation because of its favourable status under the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA). Erick Martinez, Latin America FX and rates strategist at Barclays, was quoted in the report. The Bank of Mexico’s cautious approach to rate cuts, along with predictions of easing in the United States, suggests a significant interest rate spread in favour of the peso. The real is expected to depreciate 4% in Brazil over the next 12 months from 5.46 to 5.69 per dollar. The peso in Argentina is estimated to drop 17% in 12 months to 1,465 a dollar. The real has appreciated 11.2% so far this year, and the Argentine peso has depreciated 15.7%.

title: July 4 food costs heat up as meat, egg prices climb
content: Wells Fargo says July 4 barbecues will cost 2.2% more, with beef and eggs driving prices up in 2025. Chicken, fruits & veggies offer savings.
resumen:
The July 4 cookout costs are up 2.2% year over year, driven by higher meat prices. Ground beef surges 7.4%; eggs remain 40% higher. Chicken, watermelon, and strawberries offer more budget-friendly options.

According to a new report by the Wells Fargo Agri-Food Institute, people should expect to spend about $130 this year.

The price of ground beef has surged 7.4% due to historically low cattle supply. Boneless chicken breasts are only up 1% thanks to ample supply and lower feed costs.

Buns for hamburgers and hot dogs are 1.5% cheaper, but barbecue sauce is 2.3% more, Wells Fargo says.

Prices for watermelon and strawberries are down 0.6%. Cauliflower and broccoli each saw upticks of only 1.2%; and baby carrots are up 1.9%. Cherry tomatoes will cost 3.7% more. Potatoes and ready-made cornbread experienced moderate increases of 1% and 2.4%, respectively.

Egg prices remain 40% higher, due in part to lingering impacts from the bird flu outbreak earlier in the year.

Sparkling water is up 4.7%, while wine and beer crept up about 2%.

Prepared baked goods saw little change (1.5% higher) and the cost of a 1.5-quart of ice cream rose less than 1%.

The U.S. continues to face inflationary pressures and lingering supply chain issues. The country is bracing for the Trump administration’s tariffs on imports set to take effect July 9.

A recent survey found that 1-in-3 respondents will not celebrate this year.

The average American expects to spend about $500 – which includes $200 on travel, $100 on fireworks, $80 on food, $50 on drinks and $40 on decorations.

At Stew Leonard’s stores across New Jersey, New York and Connecticut, the farm fresh grocery chain’s CEO, Stew Leonard Jr., expects the 10 biggest sellers for the holiday will be: Hamburgers, Hot dogs, Propane, Corn, Picnic salads, Cherries, Watermelon, Lobster rolls, Apple pie, and American cheese.

Stew Leonard’s is trying to hold the price of several imported goods – such as New Zealand lamb, Central American tropical fruit and Italian marinara sauce – by splitting duties.

There’s been no increase on Mexican avocados or Canadian salmon since those exports are protected under the United States-Mexico-Canada (USMCA) agreement.

Beef remains in high demand and low supply.

The egg supply is “up again post-Avian Flu” and prices are returning to normal.

title: Tariffs’ Impact On Local Businesses
content: But are the tariffs imposed so far, or the threat of tariffs, having an impact on local businesses? This week, The News-Gazette is launching an occasional series looking at the impact the tariffs may ...
resumen:
Tariffs, taxes imposed by one country on goods imported from another country, have been in the national news a lot this year. The News-Gazette is launching an occasional series looking at the impact the tariffs may or may not be having on different sectors of our local economy, starting with the region’s coffee retailers.

Since returning to office in January, President Trump has ushered in a new wave of tariffs that expand and escalate many of the trade measures first implemented during his first term. The administration’s trade policy now includes a universal 10% tariff on nearly all imports — except those from Canada and Mexico — with additional “reciprocal” tariffs ranging from 11% to 50% imposed on over 60 countries that the White House sees as unfair trade partners. These tariffs, initially rolled out during the so-called “Liberation Week” in early April, have been blamed by many for driving up costs on everyday goods.

Some of the steepest tariffs target goods from China. After briefly soaring as high as 145%, tariffs on Chinese imports were scaled back to 30% in May. Tariffs on steel and aluminum remain in place from Trump’s first term, but have been reinforced and expanded in 2025, with new 50% duties on aluminum from most countries and extended coverage to household appliances and machinery.

This tangled web of trade restrictions has added layers of cost and confusion for small businesses that depend on imported goods — including those who roast, brew and sell coffee.

The coffee industry relies on a delicate global supply chain. From green beans shipped in from Ethiopia or Colombia, to the imported parts inside a countertop espresso machine, the effects of tariffs are showing up in unexpected places.

Roadmap Coffee Works, just north of Lexington, relies on beans imported from Central and South America, East Africa, and beyond. Jack Scholl, manager of Roadmap, said, “Literally every single coffee roaster in the country except for a couple in Hawaii is importing.” Roadmap brings in beans mostly from Central and South America and East Africa, and occasionally from Indonesia.

The tariff landscape in 2025 has been less about outright disruption and more about volatility. Scholl said, “We had actually prepared for change [before tariffs increased]. The Mexico situation threw us for a loop. There was talk of a 25% tariff on Mexican imports, so we started looking for substitutes. But then coffee from Mexico was put back under the USMCA agreement, which means there’s actually no tariff now. So we went from thinking we were going to have to sever ties to Mexico to maybe bringing on even more Mexican coffee.”

Roadmap has mostly “held pat,” waiting to see how the dust settles. Roadmap doesn’t import directly, instead working through intermediary companies who handle logistics. The cost burdens are still hitting home, leading to “significant price increases” in the last year for Roadmap’s offerings. Scholl said, “Those importers are passing 100% of the tariffs on to us. Every single one of them. There’s nobody eating any of it on our behalf.”

The more dramatic force is the global spike in green coffee prices, a trend driven not by trade policy, but by climate and supply. Scholl explained, “We’ve seen a doubling in green coffee prices that has nothing to do with tariffs. Bad harvests in Brazil have seriously reduced supply, and demand just keeps going up. That’s driving prices more than anything.”

Consumers are seeing large increases in coffee prices. Scholl said, “And I want to be clear — most of that is just supply and demand. But then the tariff is there too.”

Scholl predicted, “you may start to see some coffee shops not survive if this keeps up.”

At Asunder Coffee Roasters in Buena Vista, owner Stephanie McCoy has taken a proactive approach to navigating the current wave of economic uncertainty. McCoy said, “I always prepare for the worst and hope for the best. I hate instability. Just make a decision and stick to it, even if I hate the decision.”

McCoy bulked up on beans. McCoy said, “I knew if tariffs were put on top of the prices we were already seeing, I wouldn’t be able to afford anything.”

When she first started roasting, a pound of beans from Mexico was $3.25. Now it’s $6.85. McCoy’s go-to sources are coffees from Mexico and El Salvador.

McCoy uses Cafe Imports, a Minnesota based company with a global supply network. McCoy was looking at buying a new machine for her coffee bus, and the site said, ‘Buy before May 31 or the price is going up $75.’ She didn’t buy it.

McCoy said, “I don’t think anything was considered. They’re trying to fix one small portion of the economy and they don’t understand trickle-down. They’re not looking at the whole picture.”

McCoy concluded with a similar statement Scholl had offered: “If this keeps up,” she said, “some coffee shops aren’t going to survive.”

title: Canada Pushes for Full Exemption from Trump’s Tariffs Amid Trade Talks
content: Canada is pushing for a full exemption from all U.S. tariffs imposed under President Donald Trumps trade policies, according to Canadian Ambassador to the U.S. Kirsten Hillman. Speaking to The Globe ...
resumen: Canada is pushing for a full exemption from all U.S. tariffs imposed under President Donald Trump’s trade policies, according to Canadian Ambassador to the U.S. Kirsten Hillman. Hillman, who also serves as Canada’s chief trade negotiator, expressed confidence in securing a comprehensive removal of levies through ongoing discussions with Washington. The renewed negotiations follow Canada’s decision to withdraw a proposed digital services tax targeting U.S. tech firms. Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney has set a July 21 deadline to finalize a trade deal with the U.S. Currently, Canadian exports face significant barriers, including a 50% tariff on steel and aluminum and a 25% tariff on automobiles. Additional 25% duties apply to goods not covered under the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), while exports of oil, gas, and potash are subject to a 10% tariff. The administration has set a July 9 deadline for finalizing trade agreements with affected countries. Canada aims to restore tariff-free trade, strengthen its export competitiveness, and avoid further disruptions to key industries.

title: Trump Indicates Tariff Reductions May Lead to US-India Trade Agreement
content: India and the US are negotiating over a Bilateral Trade Agreement (BTA) before the crucial July 9 deadline of the 90-day pause on tariff escalation.
resumen: India and the US are negotiating over a Bilateral Trade Agreement (BTA) before the crucial July 9 deadline of the 90-day pause on tariff escalation. Donald Trump on Tuesday (local time) said the upcoming US-India trade negotiations would be to target “far, far lower tariffs” and have “a structure in place” that will allow the two nations to compete fairly. “This is going to be a very new type of opportunity—one where we can walk in and compete on a level playing field. Right now, India has not opened up its market, but I think they will...They have not done that, but we will see. If they do that, we will probably make a deal with substantially lower tariffs,” Donald Trump was quoted as saying. India and the US have been negotiating over a Bilateral Trade Agreement (BTA) before the crucial July 9 deadline of the 90-day pause on India-US tariffs escalations. At the same time, India has hardened its stand on the agricultural sector as the high-stakes trade negotiations with the United States approached a make or break stage, government sources said on Monday. The Indian team led by Chief Negotiator Rajesh Agrawal had extended its stay in Washington. Two days of Trump on US-India Trade Talks were scheduled on Thursday and Friday but the two countries have decided to extend the dialogue as both sides were trying to rush through an interim trade agreement before the crucial July 9 deadline, a day ahead of the World Trade Organization’s MC12 meeting, reported ANI. The decision to extend the US-India trade talks came as both India and the US are staring at the possibility of the resumption of 26% reciprocal tariffs on trade following expiry of the three-month window period. As part of a tit-for-tat tariff war, these punitive tariffs were announced on each other’s imports during the Trump administration on April 2. The tariffs were put on hold for 90 days but will snap back into place if both countries fail to find a deal by July 9.

title: Trump-Backed Senate Bill Pushes 500% Tariffs on Russia’s Oil Buyers; India & China in the Crosshairs
content: A bipartisan US Senate bill proposes 500% tariffs on countries like India and China for trading with Russia, aiming to curb Moscow’s war funding.
resumen: A bipartisan US Senate bill proposes 500% tariffs on products imported from countries that continue trading with Russia, particularly in oil. The bill is strongly supported by former President Donald Trump and co-sponsored by 84 senators from both parties. This legislation targets major Russian trade partners like India and China, who together purchase about 70% of Russia’s oil exports. The bill aims to pressure these nations to sever economic ties with Russia amid its ongoing war in Ukraine. If passed, the bill will grant the US President discretionary power to enforce these tariffs, potentially affecting key Indian exports such as pharmaceuticals, textiles, and IT services. The bill is slated for introduction in the Senate after the July recess. Senator Lindsey Graham described the bill as a “bone-breaking” sanction. India has increased its imports of Russian crude oil, which now accounts for nearly 40% of its total crude oil imports, amounting to approximately EUR 49 billion in the third year of the conflict. The proposed US tariffs threaten to disrupt India’s exports to the United States. India and the US are currently negotiating a major trade agreement.

title: Mercosur: Argentina consiguió el apoyo de Brasil para poder bajar aranceles a Estados Unidos
content: La LXVI reunión del Consejo del Mercado Común comenzó este miércoles en el Palacio San Martín y terminará el jueves con la cumbre de Presidentes del Mercosur en la que Javier Milei traspasará el ...
resumen:
La LXVI reunión del Consejo del Mercado Común comenzó este miércoles en el Palacio San Martín y terminará el jueves con la cumbre de Presidentes del Mercosur en la que Javier Milei traspasará el mandato pro témpore a su par de Brasil, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.

El Gobierno libertario consiguió que los brasileños le concedan el apoyo para que Argentina pueda darle a Estados Unidos 50 excepciones al Arancel Externo Común del bloque.

Los países miembros del bloque habilitaron 50 nuevos códigos NCM con preferencias arancelarias en el Mercosur.

La Nomenclatura Común del Mercosur (NCM) es el sistema de clasificación de mercancías que usan todos los países del Mercosur (Argentina, Brasil, Paraguay y Uruguay) para describir e identificar productos en el comercio internacional.

Argentina pidió este mecanismo para poder otorgar beneficios a EE.UU., ante la falta de avances en el TLC que Milei quería firmar con Donald Trump y anunció en la apertura de sesiones del Congreso el pasado 1 de marzo.

El canciller Gerardo Werthein y el embajador Luis María Kreckler viajaron reiteradamente a Washington a reunirse con funcionarios y solicitar acuerdos especiales de reciprocidad, que todavía se negocian.

Estados Unidos está pidiendo numerosos cambios en la legislación local en otra materia, como la ley de propiedad intelectual y la cuestión de los laboratorios.

El Gobierno volvió al origen en el Mercosur y en abril solicitó rebaja de aranceles que Brasil estudió y aceptó.

El lunes se eligió al diputado Eduardo Valés (Unión por la Patria) presidente de la Comisión del Mercosur en la Cámara de Diputados.

El presidente de la Comisión de Relaciones Exteriores, Fernando Iglesias (PRO aliado a LLA) es visto por Milei como un potencial embajador argentino ante la UE.

Por el principio de "nación más favorecida", las preferencias arancelarias concedidas al pedido argentino por sus socios no se limitan a Estados Unidos y se extenderán automáticamente a todos los países miembros de la OMC.

Según distintas delegaciones, como hubo acuerdo en la última reunión del GMC, se usó la vía de excepción que permite firmar los embajadores ante ALADI y MERCOSUR.

Brasil fue clave en la negociación, y terminó accediendo. Fue difícil convencer a la CAMEX (Cámara de Comercio Exterior brasileña).

Se acordó que un brasileño asuma como Coordinador de la Unidad Técnica del FOCEM, el fondo estructural del bloque.

Brasil impuso condiciones: que se limiten las reducciones arancelarias a productos que no superen el 20% del total exportado al socio que los incluya y que se evite la concentración excesiva en un solo capítulo arancelario (tope del 30%).

El texto original de Argentina, Uruguay y Paraguay buscaba ampliar las preferencias sin esas restricciones.

El Mercosur avanza en una flexibilización arancelaria que puede beneficiar a EE.UU. y a todos los socios comerciales.

title: La Junta reúne la mesa de Diálogo Social para tratar los aranceles de Estados Unidos a Europa
content: Gobierno y agentes sociales trabajan juntos para ayudar a la internacionalización de las empresas y buscar nuevos mercados ...
resumen:
La Junta de Andalucía reunió la mesa de Diálogo Social para tratar los aranceles de Estados Unidos a Europa.

Participaron en la reunión:
*   Antonio Sanz, consejero de la Presidencia, Interior, Diálogo Social y Simplificación Administrativa.
*   Carolina España, consejera de Economía, Hacienda y Fondos Europeos.
*   Ramón Fernández-Pacheco, consejero de Agricultura, Pesca, Agua y Desarrollo Rural.
*   Jorge Paradela, consejero de Industria, Energía y Minas.
*   Javier González de Lara, presidente de la CEA.
*   Óskar Martín, secretario general de UGT Andalucía.
*   Nuria López, secretaria general de CCOO Andalucía.

Se transmitió un mensaje de unidad, prudencia y templanza, defendiendo una estrategia colectiva para afrontar los retos de la imposición de aranceles.

Antonio Sanz recordó que el Gobierno andaluz "siempre ha apostado por el Diálogo Social" y se mostró convencido de que "todos juntos aportaremos soluciones para mitigar los efectos negativos de las decisiones del gobierno estadounidense". Hizo un llamamiento a la colaboración y coordinación entre el Gobierno central y las comunidades autónomas. Defendió que la Unión Europea ofrezca una respuesta firme para salvaguardar los intereses de todos sus miembros, evitando que este conflicto derive en una guerra comercial. Anunció ayudas a la internacionalización de las empresas, con medidas específicas para los sectores más perjudicados, y la búsqueda de "mercados alternativos".

Carolina España realizó un balance del impacto de los aranceles en las exportaciones andaluzas durante el primer cuatrimestre del año. El principal producto exportado a Estados Unidos sigue siendo el aceite de oliva (259,8 millones de euros en el primer cuatrimestre de 2025, el 28% de todo lo exportado por Andalucía a EEUU), con un descenso del 12,1% interanual, explicado por la reducción del precio, ya que en volumen crece de manera significativa (45,2%). Subrayó que Andalucía "ha hecho sus deberes" desde el comienzo de la legislatura, reforzando los actos de promoción en Estados Unidos y en mercados alternativos. Recordó la inminente aprobación de una nueva línea de incentivos a la internacionalización a través de Andalucía Trade.

Ramón Fernández-Pacheco expresó su preocupación por el impacto de los aranceles en los productos agroalimentarios andaluces, especialmente el aceite de oliva (casi 59.700 toneladas y 860 millones de euros de exportación en 2024) y la aceituna de mesa (164 millones de euros en 2024). Insistió en la necesidad de eliminar estos aranceles y solicitó al Gobierno de España una diplomacia más proactiva en la negociación.

Jorge Paradela destacó la política industrial con horizonte 2030, con instrumentos de apoyo financiero que superan los 700 millones de euros para 2025. Destacó una línea de incentivos integrados de competitividad y energía para las cadenas de valor industriales, la minería sostenible y los espacios productivos, dotada con 250 millones de euros. Los Incentivos Complementarios a los Incentivos Económicos Regionales (IER) para proyectos tractores de la industria manufacturera, aeroespacial y logística avanzada cuentan con 150 millones, y otros 157 millones de ayudas se han puesto a disposición del tejido industrial para impulsar diez proyectos tractores.

Javier González de Lara trasladó las principales inquietudes de los sectores y afirmó que es imprescindible una acción conjunta y coordinada para proteger el tejido empresarial andaluz. Instó a la Junta de Andalucía a reforzar su acción conjunta con Madrid y Bruselas, activando todos los mecanismos disponibles para defender los intereses andaluces, poniendo a disposición de las empresas exportadoras medidas de apoyo centradas en liquidez, promoción internacional y diversificación de mercados.

Óskar Martín planteó una serie de medidas urgentes para proteger el empleo andaluz, como la creación de un fondo de contingencia comercial, una moratoria fiscal selectiva, una mesa de seguimiento y un plan de diversificación de mercados. Defendió una estrategia de reindustrialización sostenible y subrayó que estos aranceles no deben ser asumidos por los trabajadores.

title: Mercosur celebra cumbre semestral en Argentina con la guerra comercial como telón de fondo
content: Buenos Aires, 1 jul (EFE).- El Mercosur celebrará este miércoles y el jueves en Buenos Aires su cumbre semestral, en la que se espera que el mayor bloque suramericano centre sus debates en el álgido ...
resumen:
El Mercosur celebrará su cumbre semestral en Buenos Aires el miércoles y el jueves. Argentina traspasará a Brasil la Presidencia del bloque.

Las deliberaciones se llevarán a cabo en el Palacio San Martín. El miércoles habrá una reunión del Consejo Mercado Común (CMC), integrado por los ministros de Exteriores de Argentina, Brasil, Paraguay, Uruguay y Bolivia. Se sumarán los cancilleres y representantes de los Estados asociados (Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Guyana, Panamá, Perú y Surinam).

El miércoles también se reunirán los ministros de Economía y presidentes de los Bancos Centrales. Se espera que el CMC apruebe proyectos de resolución del Grupo Mercado Común (GMC) y defina las declaraciones finales.

Los jefes de Estado deliberarán el jueves, donde Javier Milei traspasará la Presidencia a Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. Asistirán los presidentes de Paraguay, Santiago Peña, y de Uruguay, Yamandú Orsi, y Bolivia estará representada por su canciller, Celinda Sosa.

La cumbre se centrará en la agenda comercial, influenciada por el escenario global y las imposiciones arancelarias de Donald Trump, y las tensiones en Oriente Medio.

Los cancilleres se reunieron dos veces en Buenos Aires y acordaron un mecanismo para dar mayor flexibilidad en materia arancelaria. El CMC aprobará una resolución que amplía temporalmente las listas de productos con excepciones al arancel externo común.

Argentina presentó una propuesta para permitir acuerdos comerciales preferenciales de forma individual o plurilateral, pero no encontró apoyo y fue retirada.

El Mercosur avanzó en conversaciones para firmar un acuerdo de libre comercio con la Asociación Europea de Libre Comercio (EFTA) y progresó en un acuerdo con Emiratos Árabes Unidos.

El Mercosur también recibió interés de India, Pakistán y Japón. La prioridad sigue siendo el tratado de libre comercio con la Unión Europea (UE).

El Mercosur y la UE llegaron a un acuerdo político a finales de 2024. Se espera la presentación del texto jurídico definitivo y su traducción para iniciar la ratificación parlamentaria. Los suramericanos reiteraron su expectativa de suscribir el acuerdo antes de concluir este año.

title: Charlebois: What Trump’s trade war got right
content: This is the one thing the ‘Elbows Up’ crowd never understood—and still doesn’t. We’re not in a trade war with the U.S. There’s no war to be won. For Trump, this is about a realignment of the global ...
resumen: U.S. President Donald Trump’s trade policies have been widely mocked, criticized, and condemned. The Wall Street Journal likened his tariff-heavy approach to global trade as a direct path toward another Great Depression. The U.S. economy continues to outperform expectations. The Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta projects second-quarter GDP growth at 3.8%. In May, the U.S. economy added 139,000 jobs, while inflation remained subdued at 0.1% month-over-month and 2.4% annually. The U.S. trade deficit has been cut nearly in half. Canada is showing signs of economic strain. The national economy is shrinking, manufacturing is struggling under U.S. trade pressure, and food inflation is outpacing general inflation. The Trump administration has now halted all trade negotiations with Canada. For the U.S., Canada is no longer a priority. Access to Canada's largest trading partner is narrowing. Trump is not destroying the U.S. economy. He has withdrawn U.S. support from key global institutions such as the WHO and is threatening to sever ties with others, including NATO and several UN-affiliated agencies. Among them is the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO). A senior FAO official acknowledged that fundraising dynamics have shifted. Many countries are quietly aligning with the U.S. position, scrutinizing globalist institutions with renewed skepticism. Globalism pushed the world to believe that trade liberalization was the only viable path to growth and prosperity. Globalism has made some nations — and some people — richer, while leaving others behind. Domestic sectors, including agriculture, were often sidelined or sacrificed in the name of global efficiency. The problem with globalism, particularly in agri-food policy, is its tendency to pursue uniformity over relevance. Trump’s message is that one-size-fits-all global policies rarely work. Nations have different socio-economic realities, and those should come first. For Canada’s agri-food sector, striking a better balance between global commitments and national imperatives is overdue. Sylvain Charlebois is the Director of the Agri-Food Analytics Lab at Dalhousie University and co-host of The Food Professor Podcast. He is currently a Visiting Scholar at McGill University in Montreal.

title: Trump confident of India-US trade deal with ‘much less tariffs’ ahead of July 9 deadline
content: President Trump expresses optimism about a new India-US trade deal with significantly reduced tariffs before the July 9 deadline ...
resumen: U.S. President Donald Trump expressed strong confidence that India and the United States are on the cusp of finalising a trade deal that will feature "much less tariffs," fostering increased competition between the two nations. High-stakes bilateral trade agreement (BTA) negotiations enter a critical phase, with a looming July 9 deadline. If no agreement is reached by the July 9 deadline, the suspended 26 per cent reciprocal tariffs, initially imposed during the Trump administration on April 2, will automatically be reimplemented. A senior official warned that the "failure of these trade discussions would trigger the immediate reimplementation of the 26 per cent tariff structure." The Indian delegation, led by Chief Negotiator Rajesh Agrawal, has extended its stay in Washington to urgently finalise an interim trade agreement. The United States is advocating for reduced duties on agricultural products such as apples, tree nuts, and genetically modified crops, India is seeking preferential access for its labour-intensive exports. These include vital sectors like textiles and garments, gems and jewellery, leather goods, and specific agricultural products like shrimp, oilseeds, grapes, and bananas. Both India and the U.S. are pursuing a comprehensive bilateral trade agreement (BTA), with the first phase aimed for completion by Fall 2024. Their ambitious long-term goal is to substantially increase bilateral trade, targeting $500 billion by 2030, more than double the current $191 billion.

title: ASPI USA roundtable: How Australia and US can work with Prabowo’s Indonesia
content: On the Indo-Pacific geopolitics gameboard, Indonesia stands as a potentially pivotal piece—a country whose strategic choices could reshape regional dynamics for decades. Yet, as revealed during a ...
resumen:
Indonesia, under President Prabowo Subianto, appears as a power adrift, lacking the vision and institutional capacity to realize its ambitions.

A recent panel discussion hosted by ASPI USA focused on the security relationship between Indonesia, Australia, and the US.

Indonesia possesses the geographic expanse, population, and economic potential to be a leading regional player, but its foreign policy is stuck in strategic incoherence.

Presidential personality plays an outsized role in Indonesian foreign policy.

Prabowo hasn’t really explained how he seeks to achieve his vision of Indonesia as a great power.

Personalized decision-making disconnected from institutional wisdom is a concerning pattern.

The US and Australia need to begin with the priorities set by President Prabowo to create jobs, eradicate poverty, and make Indonesia stronger and smarter.

Indonesia is looking beyond the Association of Southeast Asian Nations while maintaining its nonaligned foreign policy.

Indonesia’s January accession to BRICS reflects Prabowo’s way of trying to find leverage in a complex strategic environment.

Indonesia’s strategic ambitions and its capacity to implement them are often misaligned.

The global maritime fulcrum envisioned by former president Joko Widodo never materialized.

Indonesia’s attempt to revive the Indian Ocean Rim Association stalled.

Indonesia’s much touted ASEAN Indo-Pacific strategy has become merely a notable notion with little to back it.

Indonesia’s tendency to announce ambitious initiatives that subsequently wither from neglect damages its reputation as a reliable partner.

Indonesia’s vague strategic direction may make it a less dependable partner in regional security arrangements, but this very uncertainty also presents engagement opportunities for both Washington and Canberra.

Both the US and Australia would benefit from engagement strategies that strengthen Indonesia’s foreign policy institutions rather than focusing exclusively on personal diplomacy with Prabowo.

The most valuable Western contribution to Indonesian foreign policy may be support for the development of robust policy institutions that can provide continuity and strategic depth.

The most advantageous areas for the US, Australia, and Indonesia lie in multisectoral opportunities such as agriculture, higher education, and healthcare.

Prabowo’s administration is pursuing bold, populist initiatives that can be met with international collaboration.

In agriculture, Prabowo is leading an ambitious initiative that provides free food to school students.

The US and Australia can support this resource-intensive initiative, given their key supplier roles in soybeans and dairy.

Increased focus on food security in Indonesia opens doors in the agricultural technology sector, including logistics, fertilisers, and GMO crops.

Investment in higher education provides valuable opportunities for international collaboration.

The Indonesia Endowment Fund for Education, a scholarship focusing on overseas education, has pivoted to domestic education to boost student numbers.

The US and Australia could establish campuses in Indonesia, enhancing cross-cultural competency between the nations, facilitating foreign investment, and strengthening Indonesia’s talent base.

Indonesian Minister of Health Budi Gunadi Sadikin is seeking to completely remake Indonesia’s healthcare infrastructure.

Indonesia has introduced a new program providing annual health checkups that would eventually extend to all citizens.

The US and Australia could support this program by providing advanced medical devices, hospital system and insurance models, and clinical expertise.

If Prabowo connects on these opportunities, Indonesia could find itself in a more stable position to improve its critical infrastructure, build up its workforce, and establish long-term relationships for foreign investment.

Indonesia’s current foreign policy approach—drifting between great power nostalgia and diplomatic entrepreneurialism without institutional ballast—falls short of what the moment requires.

The real challenge is whether Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and President Donald Trump can focus on Indonesia before the opportunity slips away.

Australia may need Indonesia more than Indonesia needs Australia, and the US cannot afford to lose Indonesia as a strategic partner.

The Indo-Pacific needs an Indonesia that knows what it wants and has the institutional capacity to pursue it.

Patrick Centeno is an analyst intern and Greg Brown is director of regional cooperation and coordination at ASPI USA.

title: US, Indo-Pacific partners agree to strengthen maritime, critical minerals cooperation
content: WASHINGTON — The United States. Australia, India and Japan have agreed to expand their cooperation on maritime security in the Indo-Pacific and further collaborate on supplies of critical minerals and ...
resumen: The United States, Australia, India, and Japan have agreed to expand their cooperation on maritime security in the Indo-Pacific and further collaborate on supplies of critical minerals and rare earths. The foreign ministers of the four countries, known as the “Quad,” met in Washington on Tuesday. Secretary of State Marco Rubio said the Quad must be a “vehicle for action” and stressed that commerce and trade will be critical to ensuring the group’s relevance in the future. The four announced the creation of a “Quad Critical Minerals Initiative” that aims “to strengthen economic security and collective resilience by collaborating on securing and diversifying critical mineral supply chains.” The statement did not provide details of the initiative. They expressed concern about the abrupt constriction and future reliability of key supply chains, specifically for critical minerals, including the use of non-market policies and practices. The statement did not mention China by name. The ministers expressed specific concern about rising tensions in the East and South China Seas. They reiterated their strong opposition to any unilateral actions that seek to change the status quo by force or coercion. They expressed serious concerns regarding dangerous and provocative actions, including interference with offshore resource development, the repeated obstruction of the freedoms of navigation and overflight, and the dangerous maneuvers by military aircraft and coast guard and maritime militia vessels, especially the unsafe use of water cannons and ramming or blocking actions in the South China Sea. The ministers also condemned North Korea for continuing to launch ballistic missiles, expand its nuclear weapons program and engage in malicious cyberactivity. They expressed “deep concern about countries that are deepening military cooperation with North Korea, which directly undermines the global nonproliferation regime.”

title: Jaishankar calls for ‘equilibrium’ with China, stronger convergence with US amid Indo-Pacific tensions
content: Jaishankar on Tuesday called for establishing an “equilibrium” in India-China ties that safeguards New Delhi’s interests, while also emphasising the need to deepen strategic convergence with the US am ...
resumen:
On Tuesday, External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar called for establishing an “equilibrium” in India’s relationship with China that safeguards New Delhi’s interests, while also emphasising the need to deepen strategic convergence with the United States amid rising tensions in the Indo-Pacific.

Jaishankar discussed India’s strategic positioning in the Indo-Pacific amid rising tensions between the United States and China during a fireside chat with Newsweek.

Jaishankar noted that the evolving dynamic between Washington and Beijing has taken on a more sharply competitive tone, with significant implications for countries like India.

Jaishankar said, “There are certain realities of the landscape. One of them is that the relationship between the US and China is not what it used to be. That is, it has acquired a much sharper competitive edge… There’ll be an element of tactics to it. There’s a larger strategic view that they have of each other that we would look, quite honestly, to see in what way our interests are furthered in this landscape.”

Jaishankar emphasised the importance of establishing a balanced India-China relationship that safeguards India’s interests, while simultaneously deepening areas of convergence with the United States to maximise strategic and economic gains.

Jaishankar said, “In many ways we have very strong convergences with the United States. At the same time, we are China’s largest neighbour… We want stable relations with China. They’re a very large trade partner as well, a very imbalanced trade, but still a very large trade account. For how to steady the China relationship, create an equilibrium that is fair to us. At the same time, how do you work the convergences with the United States and get the most out of it that’s frankly the way we would approach it.”

The India-China relationship was expected to stabilise after both sides reached an agreement in October last year on patrolling arrangements in the Depsang Plains and Demchok, two key friction points along the Line of Actual Control (LAC).

Jaishankar highlighted the strategic importance of the Quad alliance, comprising India, the US, Japan, and Australia, in promoting regional stability and prosperity.

Jaishankar noted that the first international engagement of the Trump 2.0 administration was a Quad meeting.

Jaishankar declared the Quad as an equal partnership among four nations positioned at the “four corners of the Indo-Pacific”, working collaboratively to foster stability and prosperity in region and that the grouping had worked on several issues unrelated to the group’s primary concern over China’s dominance in the region.

Jaishankar said, “The quad is a very interesting mechanism, partly because it was an international commitment which resurfaced during President Trump’s first administration… It was a new commitment made by the United States under President Trump. There’s been a lot of progress since 2017 when it was restarted and again, it was interesting that the first international meeting of the Trump 2.0 administration started with a quad meeting.”

Jaishankar outlined the QUAD’s objectives, including maritime safety and security, connectivity, technology, pandemic preparedness, and education, with a focus on creating a stable and prosperous Indo-Pacific region.

Jaishankar added, “There are a lot of issues that we need to discuss in the Indo-Pacific. Issues about maritime safety and security, issues about connectivity, issues of technology, issues of pandemic preparedness, and issues of education. You have four countries in a way - four corners of the Indo-Pacific - who have decided that they have a shared interest in creating a stable more prosperous Indo Pacific and are willing to work on a very practical basis. It’s a kind of equal arrangement where everybody pays their fair share as you go along.”

The Quad is a diplomatic partnership among Australia, India, Japan, and the US, committed to supporting an open, stable, and prosperous Indo-Pacific region that is inclusive and resilient.

title: Dólar cae a S/ 3.54, nivel no visto desde inicios de pandemia ¿seguirá a la baja?
content: El precio del dólar en el Perú ha descendido fuertemente en los últimos meses, hasta llegar recientemente hasta el umbral de los 3.54 soles. Se trata de su punto más bajo en los últimos cinco años, lu ...
resumen:
El precio del dólar en el Perú ha descendido fuertemente en los últimos meses, llegando a 3.54 soles. Se trata de su punto más bajo en los últimos cinco años, luego de tocar estos niveles al inicio de la cuarentena en el Perú por la pandemia del coronavirus (13 de marzo del 2020), según datos del Banco Central de Reserva (BCR).

El profesor de Economía de la Universidad del Pacífico (UP), Enrique Castellanos, explicó que la caída del dólar en los últimos tres meses ha sido constante y actualmente se encuentra entre los 3.53 y 3.54 soles, niveles que no se veían desde antes de la pandemia.

Uno de los principales motivos es la expectativa de una baja de las tasas de interés en dólares. Se espera que la Reserva Federal (Fed) reduzca las tasas de interés en lo que resta del 2025 y que esta tendencia continúe en el 2026. Esta proyección genera que muchos inversionistas retiren sus capitales en dólares hacia monedas más fuertes como el euro o la libra esterlina. Se ha generado una depreciación global del dólar. Ha retrocedido frente al euro (de 1.04 a 1.18), la libra esterlina (de 1.25 a 1.38) y también el yen.

El Perú mantiene una balanza de pagos positiva, lo que también estaría favoreciendo al sol sobre el dólar. Están ingresando más dólares de los que salen. Esto se debe a los buenos precios del cobre y el oro, a los récords en exportaciones agrícolas, que podrían alcanzar los 15,000 millones de dólares este año, y a una campaña positiva de la exportación de harina de pescado.

Ana Lucía Rondón, asociada de Inversiones de Prima AFP, coincidió en que el fortalecimiento del sol responde también al contexto macroeconómico del país. El Perú mantiene una posición fiscal sólida y una cuenta corriente equilibrada. Hay menor volatilidad en el tipo de cambio, lo que genera confianza para invertir en instrumentos en soles. Esta tendencia a la baja y el debilitamiento más pronunciado del dólar se produjo desde comienzos de abril, "en coincidencia con el denominado 'Liberation Day' y el anuncio de aranceles por parte de Donald Trump a varios países, lo que intensificó las tensiones comerciales a nivel global" y, en su defecto, provocó el descenso del billete verde.

Ambos expertos coinciden en que el precio del dólar podría seguir bajando. Tranquilamente puede continuar esta tendencia, incluso por debajo de los 3.50 soles. Las proyecciones apuntan a un tipo de cambio cercano a los 3.55 soles por dólar en el tercer trimestre y alrededor de los 3.50 soles hacia fines de año. De mantenerse el escenario actual, se espera que el dólar fluctúe entre los 3.50 y 3.60 soles durante el resto del año.

title: Fed Chair Jerome Powell blames Trump tariffs for high interest rates
content: The central bank chief said he believes the Fed board would have decided to lower rates further until Trump launched his mercurial on-again, off-again tariffs policy, which could wind up raising ...
resumen:
Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell blamed President Trump’s unpredictable trade war for keeping interest rates stubbornly high.

Powell said the Fed board was planning to lower rates until Trump launched his mercurial on-again, off-again tariffs policy, which could wind up raising prices for American consumers.

Powell said at a banking conference in Portugal, “We went on hold when we saw the size of the tariffs. All inflation forecasts for the United States went up materially as a consequence of the tariffs.”

The Fed has kept interest rates steady for several months.

Powell noted that the Fed is likely to lower rates later in the year.

Powell said, “A solid majority of (Fed officials) do expect that it will become appropriate later this year to begin to reduce rates again.”

Two Fed board members have said they support cutting rates at the upcoming July meeting.

Powell insisted he “wouldn’t take any meeting off the table or put it directly on the table” for a potential rate cut.

Trump has bitterly attacked Powell for keeping interest rates too high.

Trump issued a handwritten message to Powell demanding that he cut rates by a massive 1% or 2%.

Trump has threatened to fire Powell but backed off down.

Powell brushed off Trump’s sniping, suggesting he has no plans to leave before his term expires next May.

Powell said, “I have a little more than 10 months left on my terms as chair. I want to hand over to my successor an economy in good shape.”

resumen:
El Gobierno de Nicaragua acusó a la Administración estadounidense de Donald Trump de intentar «destruir» a la «revolución cubana».

El Ejecutivo sandinista denunció «la continuidad del acoso y el bloqueo contra el pueblo heroico de Cuba».

Daniel Ortega y Rosario Murillo señalaron que el Gobierno de los Estados Unidos de Norteamérica solo pone en evidencia su malsana y odiosa intención de destruir un país, un pueblo y una revolución.

El lunes, el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, firmó un memorando para endurecer la política estadounidense hacia Cuba y restringir ciertas transacciones financieras y de viaje.

El documento «pone fin a las prácticas económicas que benefician desproporcionadamente al gobierno, las fuerzas armadas, las agencias de inteligencia o de seguridad cubanas a expensas del pueblo cubano», informó la Casa Blanca.

El Gobierno estadounidense prohíbe las transacciones financieras «directas o indirectas con entidades controladas por los militares cubanos, como el Grupo de Administración Empresarial SA (Gaesa) y sus afiliadas».

Se hará cumplir con «la prohibición legal del turismo estadounidense a Cuba» a través de auditorías periódicas y el control de registros de todas las transacciones relacionadas con viajes durante al menos cinco años.

Estas nuevas medidas revierten la revocación de la Administración del expresidente Joe Biden.

title: ALBA-TCP revisa Acuerdo de Cooperación ALBA Azul con autoridades de Venezuela
content: ALBA Azul es una “iniciativa que permite una amplia cooperación entre los países miembros de la Alianza para aumentar el comercio intra-ALBA”.
resumen:
La Alianza Bolivariana para los Pueblos de Nuestra América (ALBA-TCP) informó que sostuvo un encuentro de trabajo con el ministro del Poder Popular para Pesca y Acuicultura de Venezuela, Juan Carlos Loyo, a fin de revisar todos los temas en el marco del Acuerdo de Cooperación ALBA Azul.

ALBA Azul es una “iniciativa virtuosa que permite una amplia cooperación entre todos los países miembros de la Alianza para aumentar el comercio intra-ALBA como bloque”.

Este acuerdo tiene el propósito de producir alimentos a través de la acuicultura y conservar los recursos pesqueros compartidos.

Durante el encuentro, resaltaron las fortalezas conjuntas del sector pesquero de los países del bloque, que calificaron como “formidables e impresionantes”, debido a la existencia de resultados.

Evaluaron “más de 1.1 millones de kilómetros cuadrados, casi 350,000 toneladas de producción en el año 2024, y 144,940 pescadores y pescadoras como la fuerza productiva de la Alianza”.

El Acuerdo de Cooperación ALBA Azul contribuirá a «facilitar el flujo de bienes y servicios, así como utilizar y ampliar las capacidades existentes en materia de investigación y desarrollo, identificando proyectos conjuntos aplicados en pesca y acuicultura con énfasis en la sostenibilidad ambiental».

La cooperación ALBA Azul destaca tres ámbitos: «la soberanía alimentaria como pilar estratégico que requiere fortalecer nuestras capacidades productivas mediante la cooperación tecnológica, el intercambio de mejores prácticas y la formación de recursos humanos especializados».

También apuesta por promover iniciativas dirigidas a la complementariedad económica regional, para «crear cadenas de valor integradas y mecanismos financieros adaptados a las realidades de nuestros países».

Además de la adopción de una estrategia para impulsar producciones y proteger a las economías locales del impacto de los aranceles de la administración de Donald Trump y las medidas de presión de Estados Unidos (EE.UU.) Al mismo tiempo, busca garantizar un disfrute más efectivo del derecho a la alimentación de los pueblos.

title: Por qué a Trump podría interesarle un dólar débil y cómo la moneda estadounidense está cayendo a sus niveles más bajos en 3 años
content: Podría parecer un contrasentido que la Casa Blanca prefiera un dólar debilitado, pero algunos analistas aseguran que eso es lo que quiere Trump. Te contamos por qué.
resumen: El dólar tiene su peor comienzo de año desde 1973. La moneda estadounidense ha caído más del 10 % en los primeros seis meses del año en comparación con una cesta de divisas fuertes. Economistas plantean que el descenso podría explicarse por factores como la política arancelaria del presidente Donald Trump, la preocupación por un posible aumento de la inflación, baja en el crecimiento y el crecimiento de la deuda pública en EE.UU., en medio de un clima de pérdida de confianza en el papel de EE.UU. como centro del sistema financiero mundial. El valor del dólar sigue descendiendo. En medio de un aumento de las tensiones por la guerra comercial iniciada por Donald Trump desde que regresó en enero a la Casa Blanca, la moneda estadounidense continúa debilitándose. Esta semana profundizó su caída luego que la actividad industrial de EE.UU. se redujera en mayo por tercer mes consecutivo, acercando el valor del billete verde a su nivel más bajo desde el año 2023. Algunos bancos de inversión como Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan y Goldman Sachs, pronostican mayores caídas del dólar en el futuro ante una escalada de la guerra comercial y un potencial debilitamiento de la economía más grande del mundo. "El dólar ha bajado por la política proteccionista y errática de Trump que está erosionando la reputación de EE.UU.", le dice a BBC Mundo Gabriela Siller, directora de Análisis Económico en Grupo Financiero BASE, con sede en México. Según Siller, las decisiones del presidente afectan las expectativas de crecimiento de EE.UU, y siembran dudas sobre el estatus del dólar como una divisa de refugio de las inversiones y como la mayor moneda de reserva del mundo. Una de las consecuencias directas de la caída del dólar es que las exportaciones estadounidenses se vuelven más competitivas en el mercado internacional, ya que son más baratas para los compradores extranjeros. Lo contrario pasa en el sentido inverso. Los productos importados que ingresan a EE.UU. suben de precio. La depreciación del dólar también podría hacer que la Reserva Federal no quiera bajar las tasas de interés por el aumento del precio de los productos importados y, en consecuencia, de la inflación. A muchos economistas les preocupa que la caída reciente del dólar refleje algo mucho más inquietante: una pérdida de confianza en Estados Unidos. "La confianza global y la dependencia en el dólar se construyeron durante medio siglo o más", dijo a fines de abril el economista Barry Eichengreen, de la Universidad de California en Berkeley. "Pero se pueden perder en un abrir y cerrar de ojos". Trump quiere "restaurar la gloria" del sector manufacturero estadounidense. Históricamente, un dólar fuerte ha sido fomentado por los sucesivos gobiernos estadounidenses durante décadas, ya que ayuda a mantener bajos los costos de endeudamiento del país y, desde una perspectiva más geopolítica, le permite a EE.UU. proyectar una imagen de poder en el extranjero. También le ayuda a poner presión sobre otros países que no son aliados, como Irán, Rusia o Venezuela, limitándoles el acceso a su moneda, lo que les dificulta acceder a dólares para comerciar con otros países. Sin embargo, hay analistas que señalan que el gobierno de Trump ve las cosas de otra manera. Según estas versiones, el presidente considera que la fortaleza del billete verde es un obstáculo para la revolución manufacturera estadounidense que quiere impulsar. Un dólar débil, le ayudaría a "restaurar la gloria" del sector manufacturero, volviendo a la "era dorada" de EE.UU. "Trump no quiere un dólar fuerte porque aumenta las importaciones", dice Siller. Según analistas, el gobierno de Trump cree que un dólar más debilitado es positivo para que más empresas fabriquen productos en EE.UU. Desde el punto de vista de Trump, el país necesita un dólar más débil para impulsar la fabricación de productos dentro de sus fronteras, recuperar el empleo en el sector manufacturero, impulsar las exportaciones, y ayudar a reducir el enorme déficit comercial del país. Versiones extraoficiales señalan que existe un plan conocido como el "Acuerdo de Mar-a-Lago", propuesto por Stephen Miran, presidente del Consejo de Asesores Económicos de Trump, para debilitar el dólar. Este plan estaría basado en la idea de que la condición del dólar como moneda de reserva mundial no es un privilegio, sino una costosa carga que ha jugado un papel importante en la desindustrialización de la economía estadounidense. La demanda global de dólares, según este argumento, eleva su valor, encareciendo los productos fabricados en Estados Unidos y esto, a su vez, genera déficits comerciales persistentes e incentiva a los fabricantes estadounidenses a trasladar la producción al extranjero, destruyendo los empleos locales. "El plan de Miran, por astuto que parezca, se basa en un diagnóstico erróneo", escribió Kenneth Rogoff, profesor de economía y políticas públicas en la Universidad de Harvard y execonomista jefe del Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI). Economistas advierten que la bajada del dólar está relacionada con la pérdida de confianza de los inversores en EE.UU. Si bien el papel del dólar como principal moneda de reserva mundial influye, apunta el economista, "es solo uno de los muchos factores que contribuyen a los persistentes déficits comerciales de Estados Unidos". Y si el déficit comercial tiene múltiples causas, "la idea de que los aranceles puedan ser la panacea es, en el mejor de los casos, dudosa", agrega. Ningún presidente maneja el valor del dólar en relación a otras monedas porque el tipo de cambio se mueve libremente. Washington no puede intervenir directamente para que la moneda suba o baje, dado que su valor está determinado por un enorme mercado mundial de divisas y son los grandes inversores los que compran o venden dólares de acuerdo a sus expectativas. La política económica del gobierno estadounidense envía señales al mercado y eso influye en cómo evoluciona el valor del dolar y en otros factores clave como las tasas de interés. Todo esto funciona como un engranaje delicado en el que el movimiento de una pieza afecta a las otras. Así ocurrió en abril, cuando las idas y venidas de los anuncios de Trump sobre aranceles terminaron socavando la confianza de los inversores y dañando los bonos estadounidenses. "Ninguna otra moneda u otro activo, como el yuan, el bitcoin o el oro, es lo suficientemente grande como para satisfacer toda la demanda", sostuvo Steve Ricchiuto, economista de la firma Mizuho Financial. Los consumidores estadounidenses están atentos a una posible subida inflacionaria, en la medida que estarán pagando precios más altos por los productos importados, tanto por la imposición de aranceles como por la caída del dólar.

title: Dólar cae a S/ 3.54, nivel no visto desde hace 5 años ¿seguirá a la baja?
content: El precio del dólar en el Perú ha descendido fuertemente en los últimos meses, hasta llegar recientemente hasta el umbral de los 3.54 soles. Se trata de su punto más bajo en los últimos cinco años, lu ...
resumen:
El precio del dólar en el Perú ha descendido fuertemente en los últimos meses, llegando a 3.54 soles. Se trata de su punto más bajo en los últimos cinco años, luego de tocar estos niveles al inicio de la cuarentena en el Perú por la pandemia del coronavirus (13 de marzo del 2020), según datos del Banco Central de Reserva (BCR).

El profesor de Economía de la Universidad del Pacífico (UP), Enrique Castellanos, explicó que la caída del dólar en los últimos tres meses ha sido constante y actualmente se encuentra entre los 3.53 y 3.54 soles, niveles que no se veían desde antes de la pandemia.

Uno de los principales motivos es la expectativa de una baja de las tasas de interés en dólares. Se espera que la Reserva Federal (Fed) reduzca las tasas de interés en lo que resta del 2025 y que esta tendencia continúe en el 2026. Esta proyección genera que muchos inversionistas retiren sus capitales en dólares hacia monedas más fuertes como el euro o la libra esterlina. Se ha generado una depreciación global del dólar. Ha retrocedido frente al euro (de 1.04 a 1.18), la libra esterlina (de 1.25 a 1.38) y también el yen.

El Perú mantiene una balanza de pagos positiva, lo que también estaría favoreciendo al sol sobre el dólar. Están ingresando más dólares de los que salen. Esto se debe a los buenos precios del cobre y el oro, a los récords en exportaciones agrícolas, que podrían alcanzar los 15,000 millones de dólares este año, y a una campaña positiva de la exportación de harina de pescado.

Ana Lucía Rondón, asociada de Inversiones de Prima AFP, coincidió en que el fortalecimiento del sol responde también al contexto macroeconómico del país. El Perú mantiene una posición fiscal sólida y una cuenta corriente equilibrada. Hay menor volatilidad en el tipo de cambio, lo que genera confianza para invertir en instrumentos en soles. Esta tendencia a la baja y el debilitamiento más pronunciado del dólar se produjo desde comienzos de abril, "en coincidencia con el denominado 'Liberation Day' y el anuncio de aranceles por parte de Donald Trump a varios países, lo que intensificó las tensiones comerciales a nivel global" y, en su defecto, provocó el descenso del billete verde.

Ambos expertos coinciden en que el precio del dólar podría seguir bajando. Tranquilamente puede continuar esta tendencia, incluso por debajo de los 3.50 soles. Las proyecciones apuntan a un tipo de cambio cercano a los 3.55 soles por dólar en el tercer trimestre y alrededor de los 3.50 soles hacia fines de año. De mantenerse el escenario actual, se espera que el dólar fluctúe entre los 3.50 y 3.60 soles durante el resto del año.
