title: FedEx shares slide as trade turbulence hits demand, profit forecast
content: FedEx shares fell on Wednesday after the logistics giant forecast current-quarter profit below expectations, pressured by U.S. tariffs and President Donald Trump’s move to revoke duty-free status on ...
resumen:
FedEx shares fell on Wednesday after the logistics giant forecast current-quarter profit below expectations, pressured by U.S. tariffs and President Donald Trump’s move to revoke duty-free status on certain consumer shipments from China.

Shares of FedEx were down six per cent in premarket trade, while rival UPS fell about one per cent. German peer DHL also dropped nearly two per cent.

CEO Raj Subramaniam said the global demand environment remains volatile, as the company failed to provide full-year earnings and revenue forecasts, pointing to uncertainties surrounding U.S. trade policies.

The Trump administration in April imposed a tariff rate of 145 per cent on China that intensified a global trade war, before reducing it to 30 per cent in May. Executives said they expect tariff policies to continue weighing on the U.S.-China air trade transit.

The biggest hit is from the Trump administration ending duty-free status for direct-to-consumer shipments, valued at less than US$800, from China-linked bargain sellers like Temu and Shein, FedEx Chief Customer Officer Brie Carere said.

FedEx’s “cost cutting drive is continuing, but it’s clear that it’ll face more challenges ahead amid ongoing trade unpredictably,” said Susannah Streeter, head of money and markets at Hargreaves Lansdown.

The company’s dour outlook overshadowed a better-than-expected profit for the fourth quarter that ended May 31.

title: Trump U-Turns on China Buying Iranian Oil
content: Trump on Tuesday appeared to undermine years of US sanctions on Iran, giving its biggest customer China the green light to carry on buying its oil as he seeks to bolster a ceasefire with Israel.
resumen:
President Donald Trump on Tuesday appeared to undermine years of US sanctions on Iran, giving its biggest customer China the green light to carry on buying its oil as he seeks to bolster a ceasefire with Israel.

The announcement on social media - which surprised both oil traders and officials in his own government - could undermine the central element of Washington’s Iran policy under multiple administrations, which have sought to cut the regime’s main source of revenue by making its top export off limits.

“China can now continue to purchase oil from Iran,” the president said on Truth Social, amid a flurry of posts demanding Israel and Iran cease hostilities.

The statement landed only hours after Trump declared the Middle East rivals had agreed to a ceasefire, which got off to a shaky start with early breaches by both sides.

It follows massive US airstrikes on several of the Islamic Republic’s nuclear facilities Sunday, an offensive aimed at stopping Tehran from obtaining an atomic weapon.

Oil ticked higher on Wednesday, with Brent crude trading above $68 a barrel.

US Treasury and State Department officials handling Iranian oil sanctions were surprised by Trump’s statement and uncertain how to immediately interpret it.

In the meantime, however, Treasury will continue to strictly enforce related sanctions.

When asked about Trump’s announcement and the sanctions remaining in place during a regular press briefing in Beijing on Wednesday, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Guo Jiakun said his country “will take reasonable energy security measures in accordance with its own national interests.”

A senior White House official later signaled that sanctions would remain, saying that the president continues to call on China and others to import American oil rather than Iranian, which would be a violation of US sanctions.

The official added that Trump’s post was only intended to highlight that his actions over the past several days ensured that the Strait of Hormuz was not impacted, which the official said would have been devastating for China.

Tammy Bruce, State Department spokeswoman, declined to provide further specifics during a briefing Tuesday.

The apparent shift also comes as the Trump administration seeks to hammer out a new trade framework with China and climb down from a tariff war that saw duties reach levels high enough to cut all trade between the world’s two biggest economies.

The comments appeared to be Trump “throwing a bone” to China and Iran for cooperating in their respective talks with the US, said Mark Malek, chief investment officer at Siebert.

Allowing a specific carve out for China may be an effort by Trump to send positive signals to Beijing as he seeks a new tariff deal.

China, the world’s biggest importer, gets about 14 percent of its crude from Iran.

While China hasn’t officially purchased Iranian barrels since June 2022, third-party data providers and traders signal flows have been resilient despite broad US sanctions. That’s because the Chinese have built a supply chain outside of western control, which includes dark fleet ships and yuan-denominated payments, supporting imports of more than 1 million barrels a day.

Iran’s oil, often purchased at a discount, is vital for China’s substantial private refining sector and a crucial source of fuel for its economy, which has struggled under the weight of a slumping property sector.

Trump as recently as last month insisted all purchases of Iranian oil or petrochemical products “must stop, NOW!” and that buyers would be subject to secondary sanctions and prevented from engaging in any business with the US.

In February, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said Washington intended to squeeze Iran’s oil exports to less than 10 percent of current levels, as it renewed the “maximum pressure” campaign deployed during Trump’s first term.

As part of that effort, the US has sanctioned hundreds of oil tankers for their role in handling Tehran’s petroleum and, absent an easing in those measures, some buyers may still take a more-cautious approach.

The White House has also targeted Chinese entities that bought Iranian oil, something that could make other buyers wary.

Likewise, secondary sanctions on Iran’s sales remain in place and it’s not clear where the president’s remarks will leave those.

The sanctions were intended to force Iran to voluntarily give up uranium enrichment so that it would never be in a position to obtain a nuclear weapon.

It’s still unclear if US airstrikes over the weekend seriously damaged the country’s nuclear facilities, while the International Atomic Energy Agency still doesn’t know what happened to Tehran’s stockpile of 409 kilograms (902 pounds) of highly-enriched uranium - potentially enough for 10 nuclear warheads.

title: Dólar hoy
content: Dólar hoy en Colombia sigue de capa caída: comienzo de semana será duro | Dicen cómo viene movida del dólar en el país.
resumen: El índice del dólar estadounidense (DXY) cayó bruscamente hasta cerca de 98,00, perdiendo fuerza frente a sus principales pares debido a una disminución de la demanda de activos refugio. En Colombia, el dólar abre este martes con una TRM de 4.090 pesos, luego de haber tocado picos de hasta 4.200 pesos hace tan solo un par de días. Esta caída global del dólar se atribuye principalmente al alto el fuego entre Israel e Irán, así como a señales moderadas por parte de la Reserva Federal (Fed), detalla Investing. La gobernadora de la Fed, Michelle Bowman, expresó su disposición a reducir las tasas de interés en la próxima reunión de julio, lo cual también debilitó la divisa. Bowman argumentó que existen riesgos a la baja en el mercado laboral y que los recientes aranceles impuestos por la administración Trump han tenido un impacto limitado en la inflación. El dólar se depreció especialmente frente a divisas como el dólar neozelandés (-0,90%) y el dólar australiano (-0,81%). Los mercados ahora centran su atención en los datos del índice PCE de mayo, que podrían influir en las próximas decisiones de política monetaria. El valor del dólar en Colombia fluctúa constantemente debido a una compleja interacción de factores económicos, políticos y financieros tanto locales como internacionales. Uno de los principales determinantes es la oferta y la demanda de divisas en el mercado cambiario. Cuando hay una alta demanda de dólares, el precio del dólar sube. En cambio, si ingresan muchos dólares al país, la oferta crece y eso puede hacer que el precio del dólar baje. Otro factor clave son las tasas de interés en Estados Unidos. Si la Reserva Federal (Fed) sube las tasas, el dólar tiende a fortalecerse. En el contexto local, las decisiones del Banco de la República también influyen. Factores como la inflación, el crecimiento económico, el déficit fiscal y la balanza comercial son fundamentales. La incertidumbre política y social es otro elemento decisivo. Los precios internacionales del petróleo, impactan directamente.

title: Ag trade deficit reaches record high $20 billion through April
content: We have no plan — none — to deal with this growing trade gap,’ said one senior industry executive,” according to Pro Farmer Editors. “‘It’s not just bad policy; it’s no policy at all.'” ...
resumen: The U.S. agricultural trade deficit reached a record high of $20 billion through April. From January through April, the United States imported $78.2 billion in agricultural products while exporting just $58.5 billion. This $19.7 billion deficit is the largest ever recorded for the first four months of a year and signals that the 2025 deficit could surpass previous records. The U.S. has been in an agricultural trade deficit since 2022. In fiscal year (FY) 2023, the trade gap reached $16.7 billion and nearly doubled in FY 2024 to $31.8 billion. USDA now forecasts the FY 2025 deficit will rise to approximately $49.5 billion, which would mark the largest agricultural trade imbalance on record. In FY 2025, USDA projects that horticultural products, including fruits, vegetables, nuts, wine and other alcohols, will account for approximately 49% of total agricultural imports by value. One senior industry executive said, “‘We have no plan — none — to deal with this growing trade gap.’ It’s not just bad policy; it’s no policy at all.'" Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins has seemingly made expanding trade and market access for U.S. producers a key area of the first few months of her leadership at the USDA. Stephen Nicholson, Rabo AgriFinance global sector strategist for grains and oilseeds, says he is hopeful the agricultural trade deficit for 2025 has already reached its peak.

Productos clave como flores (13%), café especial (10%), textiles (2%) y banano y plátano (2%) enfrentan un arancel relativamente bajo en comparación con sus competidores. El 3% de la canasta, particularmente aguacate, limón Tahití, cacao y pescado, enfrenta un impacto negativo alto, ya que compite con países como México, que gozan de un arancel del 0%. En cuanto al aluminio y acero, la entrada en vigor de nuevos aranceles del 50% ad valorem sobre el contenido de acero en productos clasificados como “derivados” aplica a una amplia gama de electrodomésticos. El 40% de los productos de la canasta exportadora colombiana tiene un potencial medio-alto o alto de expansión en Estados Unidos. Entre estos destacan materiales eléctricos, textiles y confecciones, azúcares y productos de confitería. AmCham señala que es fundamental que Colombia mantenga una vigilancia técnica constante sobre los cambios en la política arancelaria estadounidense y sobre las negociaciones bilaterales que EE. UU. adelanta con otros países. Colombia debe contar con una estrategia comercial clara que le permita presentar sus intereses ante Estados Unidos y trabajar por una relación mutuamente beneficiosa. AmCham Colombia sostiene que “será clave construir una hoja de ruta comercial clara que busque la eliminación o exclusión de productos afectados por el arancel del 10%, la reducción de fricciones bilaterales y la ampliación de oportunidades bajo el TLC.

title: Why Trump’s second trade war could be worse for US farmers
content: Hemmes, a fourth-generation farmer on land her family has worked for almost 125 years in north-central Iowa, life is guided by a simple philosophy: “Prepare for the worst and hope for the best.” It’s ...
resumen: The article discusses how President Trump's recent tariff hikes on major U.S. trading partners could worsen the situation for U.S. farmers. April Hemmes, a fourth-generation farmer in Iowa, expresses concern about the uncertainty caused by the trade war. The article highlights that this second trade war comes at a time when farmers are in a more vulnerable financial position. Grain prices have been on a downward trend for the last four years, with soybeans losing 34% of their value. Net farm income has declined for three consecutive years. Input prices for fertilizer, fuel, and other essential supplies have surged in the past five years. Average interest rates on loans for land purchases and farm operations have increased by over 40% since 2020. Patrick Westhoff, director of the Food and Agricultural Policy Research Institute (FAPRI) at the University of Missouri, notes that the financial health of farmers varies by sector, with crop producers in a challenging position. Ammonium fertilizer increased by more than 15% over the past five years, and phosphorus and potassium rose by over 10%. Diesel has seen the second-largest price hike. Chad Hart, a professor of economics at Iowa State University, states that high costs and low crop prices force farmers to take on more loans, but it's getting harder to pay them back. The Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago reports that farmers are applying for more loans than a year ago. The index of repayment rates for non-real-estate farm loans has declined year-over-year for the sixth consecutive quarter. Agricultural loan interest rates have soared to historic highs. The U.S. and China reached a temporary truce on tariffs on June 11, cutting tariffs from 145% to 55% on Chinese goods and 10% on U.S. exports. Tariffs on other major trading partners, announced in April, have only been paused until July 9. The Ag Economy Barometer from Purdue University and the CME Group surveyed 400 producers from April 14 to 21, and found that 44% anticipated a negative impact on farm income in 2025, and 53% feared continuing supply disruptions. 70% believed that higher tariffs could ultimately strengthen the U.S. agricultural economy.

title: Pressure for Trump trade deals ramps up with two weeks to go
content: Two weeks from President Donald Trump’s self-imposed deadline to reach deals with the US’s major trading partners, some of the most-watched talks aimed at clinching agreements to avoid higher tariffs ...
resumen:
Two weeks from President Donald Trump’s self-imposed deadline to reach deals with the US’s major trading partners, some of the most-watched talks aimed at clinching agreements to avoid higher tariffs are struggling to get over the finish line.

As of July 9, exporting nations without a bilateral accord in place will face Trump’s so-called “Liberation Day” tariffs that are much higher than the current baseline 10% level applied to most countries.

Only the UK has secured something on paper, though that pact kept the 10% so-called reciprocal rate in place and left unresolved one of Britain’s pain points - 25% steel duties.

China has a fragile truce with the US that extends into mid-August to give time for negotiations to play out.

The administration will extend the tariff pause for those it considers to be negotiating in good faith.

Trump plans to “set the tariff rate unilaterally in ‘take it or leave it’ deals.”

Court challenges to Trump’s legal authority for tariffs have provided an added element of uncertainty for companies.

European Union: The best-case scenario remains an EU-US agreement on principles that would allow the negotiations to continue beyond the early July deadline. Trump threatened to give up and impose unilateral tariffs. The EU will assess any end-result and at that stage decide what level of asymmetry - if any - it’s willing to accept or whether it will push ahead with countermeasures to correct any imbalances.

India: Trade officials from India and the US are still keen to clinch an interim deal before the deadline, but the two sides appear to be digging in their heels on some key issues, particularly on agricultural goods. The US is seeking access to India’s markets for its genetically modified crops, a request India has denied, while New Delhi wants an exemption to the reciprocal tariffs as well as sectoral duties. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi missed an opportunity to advance the trade deal with Trump when the US leader left the Group of Seven meeting in Canada earlier than planned last week.

Vietnam: Communist Party chief To Lam is set to lead a delegation of officials and business executives to the US, aiming to meet with Trump and clinch additional deals with US firms to help finalize an agreement. The nation has offered to boost purchases of American products from Boeing airplanes to agricultural goods to get a deal. Negotiators are close to a framework agreement under which Vietnam is pushing for tariffs in the range of 20% to 25%.

Japan: US auto tariffs appear to be the key barrier to a deal between Washington and Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba’s government, which is bracing for talks to drag on. Trump and Ishiba failed to reach an agreement at the Group of Seven leaders’ summit in Canada, despite holding three prior calls to discuss the tariffs. Opposition leader Yoshihiko Noda said after a meeting with Ishiba that the US is most concerned about the auto trade deficit and that no consensus has been reached. Both sides are now trying to schedule the next round of high-level trade talks. The US is set to raise tariffs on Japan to 24%, on top of existing duties of 25% on cars and 50% on steel and aluminum.

South Korea: South Korea has yet to make meaningful progress in trade negotiations. New Trade Minister Yeo Han-koo met with US officials in Washington on June 23, aiming to secure exemptions from tariffs, including those already imposed on cars and steel. This comes after a planned meeting between President Lee Jae Myung and Trump at the G-7 summit was called off at the last minute as Trump left the event early amid rising tensions in the Middle East. South Korea faces the risk of a 25% tariff, further squeezing its export-dependent industries already strained by the sectoral duties.

Thailand: Thailand, which has been threatened with a 36% tariff, began its delayed talks with the US last week. Permanent Secretary for Commerce Vuttikrai Leewiraphan said last Wednesday that Thailand’s proposals are good and stand a chance to bring down the tariff to the 10% baseline. The official proposal was submitted to Washington last week and detailed negotiations are underway, the finance minister said Tuesday. The US was Thailand’s largest export market last year, accounting for nearly one-fifth of the country’s total outbound shipments.

Malaysia: Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said that Malaysia’s negotiations with the US have been going well after officials met with US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick in Washington. Anwar said the imposition of the US tariffs was a “significant challenge” and added that about 60% of semiconductor products from Malaysia was exported to the US alone. Malaysia is seeking to reduce the US tariffs to below 10% for sectors critical to both economies. Both sides have agreed to finalize the talks before the tariff reprieve expires, Malaysia’s trade ministry said this week.

Switzerland: The European nation, also facing among the highest tariff rates of US allies, sketched a compromise around easing market access for some agricultural products, with Economy Minister Guy Parmelin saying he aimed to reach an agreement by early July. Since then, the US Treasury added Switzerland to its list of countries monitored for foreign exchange practices earlier this month. And Trump’s erratic trade policies contributed to the Swiss central bank cutting policy rates by 25 basis points last week after a surge of the franc.

Canada: Targeted with tariffs other than the reciprocal levies, the US’s northern neighbor is seeking to make a deal by mid-July, according to Prime Minister Mark Carney who met Trump on the sidelines of the G-7 meeting. There are still differences between the two nations, according to the US president, who’s complained in the past about undocumented migration and fentanyl issues along the border. Canada is preparing to increase tariffs next month on steel and aluminum - currently at 25% - if talks stall.

Mexico: Mexico and the US were earlier this month nearing a deal that would remove Trump’s 50% tariffs on steel imports up to a certain cap. President Claudia Sheinbaum expected to meet with Trump soon after their planned encounter was canceled when he departed early from a G-7 summit in Canada. A formal start to the review of the USMCA - the free trade agreement between Canada, US and Mexico - is expected to begin later this year.

James Chu, Chairman at KGI Securities Investment Advisory, says: "The demand for AI in the short term remains stable, supporting a continued rebound in the stock market.

In 2H25, Singapore's economy is expected to experience cautious growth due to global trade uncertainties and a challenging external environment.

A 30% tariff on Chinese imports led to this decision.

About 80% of the toys Ecobuns has in stock are made in China.

Suppliers are warning that what they have now is all they will have through Christmas.

title: Trump 2.0 alienates Southeast Asia’s next generation
content: To stay ahead of China in Southeast Asia, the United States must halt Trump’s erratic global leadership style and rebuild trust through consistent respect for international law and regional engagement ...
resumen:
US President Donald Trump’s second term has deepened Southeast Asian young people’s distrust of the United States due to perceived hypocrisy, erratic trade policy and unwavering support for Israel amid its war in Gaza. Their growing disillusionment is driving a tilt toward China — seen by Southeast Asia’s youth as an imperfect but stable partner country. Trump’s unpredictable diplomacy risks accelerating US strategic decline in a region where trust and multilateral commitment are crucial. Washington generally remains Southeast Asians' preferred strategic partner — but China is increasingly seen as a more reliable alternative.

US President Donald Trump’s second term has sent the global economy into a tailspin with a torrent of tariffs announced on 2 April 2025. Trump has reinforced the United States’ regional image as a declining, unstable and unreliable hegemon among Southeast Asian young people.

Pre-election focus group discussions conducted with 33 Southeast Asian elites aged between 18 to 35 from six ASEAN countries working in the business, policymaking and civil society sectors expressed concerns about the United States. They highlighted the US administration’s Gaza strategy and Washington’s perceived lack of respect for international law.

Young people are a significant political force — as seen in recent elections in Indonesia, the Philippines and Thailand.

They also lamented Washington’s inconsistent and erratic strategy in Southeast Asia before 2024 and worried that a second Trump term would portend the return of a more isolationist United States. Young people were cognisant that a Trump-led United States would be more unpredictable than one led by former US vice president Kamala Harris, despite recognising that half-hearted US engagement with Southeast Asia would continue regardless of the administration. Trump’s early policies will have exacerbated these concerns.

Trump’s continued support for Israel stood out as an issue of particular concern for young people in majority-Muslim Indonesia and Malaysia. The majority of Southeast Asia’s youth was dismayed at the humanitarian crisis in Gaza and Israeli breaches of international law, with 75 per cent expressing that Israel’s response to the 7 October 2023 attacks had ‘gone too far’.

Washington’s rhetoric in response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine under the Biden administration contrasted with its continued support for Israel’s actions in Palestine. This led to allegations that the United States was ‘hypocritical’ as it had appeared to present a ‘higher moral standard’ in its support for Ukraine compared to its support for Gaza. Trump’s backtracking on support for Ukraine has weakened the argument about double standards.

This dismay about the United States has led many young people to a preference for China. Except for Singapore, the Philippines, and Thailand, other participants from Indonesia, Malaysia and Vietnam picked Beijing over Washington when faced with a forced binary question — drawn from the ISEAS–Yusof Ishak Institute’s annual State of Southeast Asia survey report. Participants in this smaller study spoke positively of Beijing’s Belt and Road Initiative, despite being aware of potential threats to their national security and sovereignty from engaging with China, particularly in the South China Sea.

Compared to Washington, Beijing appears to respondents as a more stable and reliable partner in advocating for the multilateral system, which Chinese President Xi Jinping has emphasised. China’s image has shown a noticeable improvement.

Older Southeast Asian respondents seemed more optimistic about Trump. According to the 2025 iteration of the institute’s report, the United States was expected to increase its Southeast Asian engagement under Trump’s leadership, while trust in the United States to ‘do the right thing’ improved from 2024.

Most importantly, Southeast Asia chose the United States over China as its preferred partner for strategic alignment after it broke with precedent in 2024 by choosing Beijing.

According to the survey, faith in Trump 2.0 largely hinged on US ability to ‘respect international law and its institutions and not undermine the global system’. Concerns included Washington’s potential foreign interference, its potential distraction by domestic affairs, continued support for Israel in the Gaza conflict and Trump’s ‘unpredictability and uncertainty’.

Though Trump 2.0 has expressed ambivalence to the fears expressed by Southeast Asia’s young people, the United States remains the region’s preferred strategic partner. But the gap between Washington and Beijing is narrowing. Washington’s trade with Southeast Asia trails behind Beijing’s, the region’s top year-on-year trade partner. Beijing is the region’s top influential economic partner and leading strategic and political influence.

Given competing visions of US foreign policy in the Republican Party and Trump’s unpredictability, discerning the Trump administration’s grand strategy for Asia is a tall order. But Trump risks ceding further ground in the United States’ strategic regional competition with China. This ultimately does not serve the interests of protectionist China-hawks nor traditional internationalist Republicans and risks destroying a largely positive regional image built up over decades. The US administration’s efforts to erode its regional standing could linger in the minds of Southeast Asian youth as they age and impact future US–Southeast Asia relations.

Sharon Seah is Senior Fellow and Coordinator at the ASEAN Studies Centre and the Climate Change in Southeast Asia Programme, ISEAS–Yusof Ishak Institute, Singapore. Eugene Tan is Research Officer at the ISEAS–Yusof Ishak Institute, Singapore. This article draws on the authors’ March 2025 study, Current Perspectives on Geopolitics among Southeast Asian Youths, published by ISEAS Publishing.

title: Latest USA Tariff Developments: Impact on Global Economy & Trade
content: Trump’s 2025 tariff spark global economic tension, raising prices, straining trade relations, and shaking markets across the US and beyond.
resumen:
Donald Trump, after taking on the White House for his second tenure, announced a series of tariffs in 2025. These tariffs are taxes charged on goods imported from other countries, calculated as a percentage of the product's value. Trump's stated goal is to encourage consumers to buy "made in America" products, boosting the US economy and increasing tax revenue.

Key dates and measures:

*   **February 14:** Changes in US tariffs and trade policies might affect the global economy and supply chain. The International Monetary Fund estimates a 10% increase in US tariff rates could affect the nation's GDP by approximately 1% and around 0.5% by 2026.
*   **February 27:** Increased tariff rates could directly affect American consumers, leading to price increases for imported goods.
*   **March 6:** A one-month respite for goods traded under the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) was negotiated.
*   **March 12:** 25% tariffs on steel and aluminum imports were announced.
*   **April 3:** A minimum of 10% tariff on all trading countries was announced, with higher rates for the EU, China, and Japan.
*   **April 9:** An additional 50% tariffs on China were imposed, taking the overall increase to 104%. China responded with an 84% tariff on US import goods.
*   **April 24:** JP Morgan research indicates that the imbalance of tariffs, 10% universal and 110% on China, can reduce the global economy by 1%.
*   **May 8:** A trade framework between the USA and the UK considers reducing import taxes on British cars and a tariff-free quota on beef, while the base 10% tariff will remain for all other goods.
*   **June 3:** The effective average tariff rates could settle somewhere between 15% to 18% after the Court for International Trade stated that tariffs imposed under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) are unlawful.

Specific Tariffs:

*   **Steel and Aluminum:** A 25% import tax was announced on all steel and aluminum, effective March 12.
*   **EU Products:** Initially, a 20% tariff was decided on most goods from the EU, but settled for 10% until July 8, later extended to July 9.
*   **China-US Trade:** Higher tariff rates on China of almost 104% led to a 145% tariff increase on Chinese imports to the US. China introduced 125% import taxes on US products. Both countries agreed to suspend some tariffs after a Geneva discussion.
*   **Canada and Mexico:** In February, 25% tariffs were introduced on Canadian and Mexican imports, and another 10% levy on Canadian energy. Canada introduced a 25% tax on imports of some US cars in April.

Impact:

*   American consumers are facing price increases for various imported goods.
*   Companies like Adidas and Mattel are increasing prices.
*   The US economy decreased in the first four months of 2025.
*   The dollar has fallen in value.
*   The International Monetary Fund (IMF) reduced its prediction of global economic growth in 2025.
*   World leaders have strongly opposed the idea of higher import tariffs.

title: Migrantes en Estados Unidos: el refrigerador vacío y el miedo invisible
content: Los latinos en Estados Unidos no solo se enfrentan a la amenaza de la deportación, sino a un aumento de la inflación y el deterioro del empleo.
resumen:
Los latinos en Estados Unidos se enfrentan a la amenaza de la deportación, el aumento de la inflación y el deterioro del empleo.
Para una mayoría de migrantes latinos, regresar del supermercado con menos bolsas y un refrigerador cada vez más vacío es una preocupación que, en momentos, pareciera más poderosa que el miedo a las políticas antiinmigrantes de Donald Trump.
Julián Placencia, un dreamer originario de México, beneficiario del programa DACA, dice que le preocupa más la economía que la migración.
Trump obtuvo el 46% del voto latino en las pasadas elecciones, 14 puntos más que en 2020, según los sondeos a pie de urna de Edison Research.
La aprobación de Trump entre los votantes hispanos y latinos ha caído al 40%, con un 56% de desaprobación, según un análisis de Newsweek.
Más del 64% de los latinos cree que su situación financiera ha empeorado, según una encuesta a cargo de Reuters/Ipsos.
La mayoría de latinos está más preocupada por los precios y la inflación que por los temas de inmigración, según YouGov/The Economist.
Carmen Luna, una mexicana que vive en Texas, dice que antes con 100 dólares compraba carne para la semana, pero ahora apenas alcanza para leche o huevo.
El precio del huevo aumentó 36.8% en un año, según el Índice de Precios al Consumidor (IPC).
Guadalupe Cambria, una mujer jubilada de California, dice que antes comía comida rápida por 8 dólares, pero ahora necesita 15.
Román Carrasco, un cubano de Texas, nota el aumento de los precios.
Las remesas a Cuba cuestan más.
Lucía Meléndez, madre de dos adolescentes en Texas, emigró de México en 1999 y se siente vulnerable en el segundo mandato de Trump.
El hijo de Meléndez no puede inscribirse en el college comunitario por una deuda de 800 dólares.
Meléndez comenzó a cortar el pasto a conocidos para completar el alquiler y se ha vuelto invisible por decisión.
Trump lanzó una serie de órdenes ejecutivas y cambios que han dejado más vulnerables a personas indocumentadas y en condición regular.
Placencia, trabaja pavimentando calles en el norte de Texas con un permiso de trabajo y tiene un ingreso de alrededor de $1000 dólares por semana.
El precio de su departamento aumentó y ahora paga tres veces más en alimentos que antes de enero.
El Senado estadounidense debate la aprobación del nuevo plan presupuestario impulsado por Trump, con el que se propone eliminar la cobertura médica que algunos estados financian para personas sin ciudadanía o estatus migratorio verificado.
Este proyecto presupuestario también incluye un impuesto de 3.5% a las remesas que millones de personas envían a sus países de origen desde Estados Unidos.
En Fort Worth, Texas, el futuro se ve oscuro.
Los hijos de Lucía recibían entre 100 y 200 dólares en vales de comida del Programa de Asistencia Nutricional Suplementaria (SNAP), pero en familia decidieron dejar de solicitarlos.

title: Jerome Powell says Fed in no rush to cut rates — as Trump calls him ‘dumb, hardheaded’
content: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell will tell lawmakers Tuesday that the central bank is in no rush to lower interest rates, underscoring a cautious stance as officials await more clarity on the ...
resumen:
Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell told US lawmakers he is in no hurry to cut interest rates.
President Trump ripped the central bank chief as “dumb” and “hardheaded” over his hawkish stance on inflation.
Powell said during his testimony on Tuesday that policymakers would cut rates in September at the earliest.
Powell told the House Financial Services Committee on Tuesday: “If it turns out that inflation pressures do remain contained, we will get to a place where we cut rates sooner rather than later, but I wouldn’t want to point to a particular meeting.”
Powell said the US economy remains on firm footing but warned of lingering inflationary pressures stemming from tariffs.
Trump’s tariffs are expected to push prices higher in the months ahead.
Powell said: “We do expect [inflation] to move [up] in the summer and if we see it not happening, we will learn from that.”
Another key factor that will inform the Fed’s decision on whether to slash interest rates is the unemployment figures.
Powell said: “If we were to see the labor market meaningfully weaken in a way that was concerning, that would matter for that decision. I don’t think we need to be in any rush because the economy is still strong, the labor market is strong.”
Powell’s risk-averse stance has riled his fiercest critics — chief among them Trump, who took to Truth Social early on Tuesday morning to blast the central bank chief as “dumb,” “hardheaded” and a “Total and Complete Moron!”.
Trump claimed the Fed’s inaction was costing the US hundreds of billions in unnecessary interest payments and urged Congress to challenge Powell’s leadership.
Fed Vice Chair for Supervision Michelle Bowman told a gathering in Prague on Monday that she supported a rate cut in July, citing delayed and muted inflation from tariffs and growing concerns about the labor market.
She said she would advocate for a reduction “as early as our next meeting” if inflation remains subdued.
Fed Governor Christopher Waller said tariff-driven inflation is minor and the Fed should “move now, don’t wait” if labor risks grow.
Powell took a neutral stance — saying that he could not predict whether inflation will remain mild.
Powell said policymakers were “perfectly open to the idea that the pass through” of tariffs into retail prices “will be less than we think. And if so, that’ll matter for our policy.”
Powell said the economy showed signs of moderation in the first quarter due to “swings in net exports” as businesses rushed to import goods ahead of looming tariffs.
Powell explained: “This unusual swing has complicated GDP measurement.”
Powell noted that “respondents to surveys of consumers, businesses, and professional forecasters point to tariffs as the driving factor” behind price increases.
Richmond Fed President Tom Barkin warned that inflation is still above target.

title: Canada and E.U. Pull Together as America Pushes Them Away
content: The European Union and Canada struck a defense agreement on Monday, a step toward closer military cooperation as relations with the United States have soured.
resumen:
Canadá firmó una asociación de defensa con la Unión Europea el lunes.

El acuerdo con la Unión Europea allanará el camino para que el país se adhiera al programa insignia en el impulso de Europa para aumentar su armamento militar, un plan de adquisición de defensa de 150 mil millones de euros (173 mil millones de dólares).

Solo el 35 por ciento de los fondos dedicados a cualquier proyecto realizado bajo el programa se pueden utilizar para comprar armas de países que no se hayan adherido al plan.

Gran Bretaña firmó uno en mayo y Australia concluyó uno la semana pasada.

Estados Unidos no tiene tal acuerdo, lo que significa que el número de bombarderos F-35, sistemas de defensa aérea Patriot y otros materiales de fabricación estadounidense que se pueden comprar a través del programa será limitado.

El acuerdo reforzará la industria de defensa de Canadá al darle un mejor acceso a los contratos de la Unión Europea.

Una revisión de 2022 encontró que aproximadamente la mitad de los productos de defensa de Canadá se exportaron, abrumadoramente a los Estados Unidos.

Ursula von der Leyen, presidenta de la Comisión Europea, dijo en Bruselas: "Tenemos una excelente asociación, entre dos democracias fuertes, unidas por lazos históricos y conectadas por una asociación comercial que es dinámica, justa y abierta".

Ms. von der Leyen el lunes calificó el nuevo acuerdo de seguridad y defensa con Canadá como "el más completo que hemos concluido".

El primer ministro Mark Carney de Canadá.

Un sondeo reciente encontró que casi el 50 por ciento de los canadienses estaban interesados en buscar una candidatura para que Canadá se uniera a la Unión Europea.

title: NATO Leader’s Aim? Give Trump What He Wants: A Win on Military Spending.
content: But at a summit focused on keeping President Trump happy, discussion of Russia is expected to be muted, despite most allies’ belief that its aggression is NATO’s chief challenge.
resumen:
When NATO leaders meet at The Hague on Tuesday, there will be much talk about President Trump and his efforts to contain Iran, but Russia will be the elephant in the room.

The looming issue for NATO is Russia, which is at the heart of the meeting focused on increased military spending.

Mr. Trump has demanded that NATO members spend a lot more money on defense.

Mark Rutte, the alliance secretary general, believes it is to deter a militarized Russia that is already at war on NATO’s borders, in Ukraine.

In April, Mr. Rutte said, “We all agree in NATO that Russia is the long-term threat to NATO territory, to the whole of the Euro-Atlantic territory.”

Mr. Trump has evinced intermittent frustration with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia but has refused to impose sanctions on Russia or even to admit that Russia is to blame for invading Ukraine. He wants to reopen economic and diplomatic relations with Moscow and has consistently belittled and undercut President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine.

At the Group of 7 summit in Canada last week, Mr. Trump left early, complained that Russia was not a part of the group and canceled a meeting with Mr. Zelensky. Mr. Trump is expected to keep his visit to The Hague similarly short, to less than 24 hours. It will be the first NATO leaders’ summit of his second term.

A new NATO strategy toward Russia and the Russian threat, to replace the approach adopted in the late 1990s, was supposed to be adopted at the summit, but the new strategy has been scrapped at Washington’s insistence, to avoid a conflict with Mr. Trump and his so far futile efforts to negotiate with Russia over Ukraine.

A session of the NATO-Ukraine Council, where the alliance leaders meet with Mr. Zelensky, was never a prospect, given Mr. Trump’s ambivalence toward the Ukrainian leader, although lower-level ministers are expected to meet.

New spending targets are meant to be the focus and the accomplishment of this brief summit, which starts Tuesday with a dinner hosted by the Dutch royal family and ends with one morning session on Wednesday followed by what is expected to be a historically short communiqué.

Mr. Rutte is skilled at handling Mr. Trump and has no embarrassment about flattering him. In an unusually unctuous message that Mr. Trump released on Tuesday, Mr. Rutte praised him for making Europe “pay in a BIG way” on increased military spending and for his “decisive action in Iran, that was truly extraordinary, and something no one else dared to do.”

To try to ensure a smooth summit, Mr. Rutte said: “Donald, you have driven us to a really, really important moment for America and Europe, and the world,” getting allies to commit to spending 5 percent of their gross domestic product on defense. “You will achieve something NO American president in decades could get done,” Mr. Rutte added. NATO officials confirmed that the message, which Mr. Trump posted on social media, was authentic.

Mr. Zelensky’s role is considerably reduced from recent summits, where his battle against Russia was a central focus. But he has agreed to come after some hesitation, according to two senior European officials. He will attend the dinner and have bilateral meetings.

The draft communiqué, if allies agree to it, does tie Russia’s aggression in Ukraine to the need to increase military spending, one of the officials said. But it makes no mention of NATO’s promise of eventual membership to Ukraine and Georgia, as previous summit communiqués have done.

Mr. Rutte’s aim is to ensure that the meeting displays unity and gives Mr. Trump a victory on increased spending. Mr. Rutte has gotten alliance agreement to commit to the spending increase to 5 percent of national income on defense, with 3.5 percent on core military needs to meet NATO’s requirements. That is a big jump from the 2 percent goal set in 2014.

In addition, allies will aim to spend another 1.5 percent of national income on militarily useful items like better roads and bridges, better emergency health care and better civilian preparation for war — a workaround to help more nations reach Mr. Trump’s goal.

The deadline to hit that goal is not yet settled and could vary. And no one expects every country to hit 5 percent, as Spain has said it cannot do, but each member will be asked to commit to meeting NATO’s new military requirements.

On Tuesday, Dmitri S. Peskov, the Kremlin spokesman, said the goal of raising military spending to 5 percent of gross domestic product fit with the West’s campaign to “demonize Russia.” He added, “They needed to come up with a boogeyman, a monster, and according to NATO officials, there is no better candidate to be this monster than Russia.”

Mr. Rutte’s overall hope is to limit the chance of division over contentious issues like Russia and aid to Ukraine — contentious, at least, for Mr. Trump and two of his populist supporters, Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary and Prime Minister Robert Fico of Slovakia.

The three leaders believe, in essence, that good relations with Russia are vital for European security, that the war in Ukraine makes NATO more vulnerable rather than less, and that NATO should spend to defend itself, not to fight Russia in Ukraine.

To that end, NATO countries are pledging billions to aid Ukraine, both financially and militarily.

The president of the Czech Republic, Petr Pavel, a former general, summarized his outlook for the summit.

Expectations for the summit are high, especially for new targets for military spending, but the goals are also limited because of the U.S. administration’s “approach.”

The communiqué was likely to lack strong language about Ukraine, even as the country faced a Russian summer offensive and diminished help from the United States.

Mr. Trump has made it clear that Europe must take the bulk of the responsibility for aiding and supplying Ukraine.

What Mr. Zelensky takes away from the summit is an open question, said Michael R. Carpenter, the former U.S. ambassador to the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.

title: De la guerra comercial a la esperanza tropical
content: Los aranceles impulsados por Trump han enfrentado recientemente una serie de obstáculos legales y políticos. Aunque el gobierno ha logrado mantenerlos en ...
resumen:
Los aranceles impulsados por Trump han enfrentado recientemente una serie de obstáculos legales y políticos. Los mercados empiezan a percibir que son más frágiles, lo que ha contribuido a un repunte en las bolsas, animado por anuncios de posibles acuerdos comerciales entre las grandes potencias.

Las cadenas de suministro más cortas, seguras y diversificadas llegaron para quedarse.

La diversificación traerá oportunidades para varios países emergentes, como los de América Latina, donde la mano de obra es más barata.

Colombia puede ser uno de los invitados a la fiesta. Se trata de una oportunidad a largo plazo y ojalá los grandes inversionistas vean ese potencial con los ojos puestos mucho más allá de 2026. Las inversiones en centros logísticos, plantas y fábricas de producción, una mejor infraestructura vial y portuaria son apenas el inicio para aprovechar las nuevas tendencias de las cadenas de suministro. Sectores como el textil, el automotriz, el calzado y varias industrias tecnológicas podrían encontrar grandes oportunidades si las cadenas de suministro empiezan a mirar hacia países en desarrollo como el nuestro.

El Gobierno nacional tiene un rol importante. Permitir estructuras eficientes, promover alianzas estratégicas entre países de la región, eliminar riesgos regulatorios y simplificar procesos es parte de esta tarea. El gobierno podría ser facilitador y puente entre capital y oportunidad, entre inversionistas que miran al futuro y empresas locales que quieren crecer.

Colombia tiene una oportunidad de oro, y capitalizarla no será tarea exclusiva del Gobierno de turno. También dependerá del sector privado, que debe tener la visión de posicionar al país como un destino atractivo para que las grandes empresas inviertan y relocalicen su producción. Contamos con un capital humano calificado, una mano de obra competitiva en costos y la ventaja geográfica de tener salidas tanto al Pacífico como al Caribe.

title: A resilient, well-supplied oil market is less reactive to geopolitical tensions: Experts
content: Given ample supplies and low demand, the market looks for real impact on supplies for cues rather than offer knee-jerk responses to perceived threats, experts say.
resumen: Experts say a resilient, well-supplied oil market is less reactive to geopolitical tensions. The price of crude oil slumped on June 24 to pre-Iran-Israel conflict levels, trading around $65-66 per barrel. The price spike was on the back of the possibility that Iran would shut the Strait of Hormuz, through which 20 percent of global oil supply passes. Brent crude briefly touched highs of around $78–80 per barrel during the conflict before falling more than 7 percent on June 24. In the 2024 Iran-Israel conflict and the outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine war, prices shot up to highs of $90 per barrel and $120 a barrel, respectively. Iran’s threats of blocking the Strait of Hormuz had no serious repercussions to the oil market. The oil supply was undisrupted during the 12-day war between Israel and Iran, which began on June 13. The Strait of Hormuz connects the Persian Gulf with the Gulf of Oman, extending onward to the Arabian Sea. The strait is only 33 km wide at its narrowest point. About 20 percent or one-fifth of the total global oil output passes through the strait. OPEC accounts for around 40 percent of total global oil production. Crude oil prices have softened and have been hovering in the range of $65-70 per barrel in 2025. Average crude oil prices were in the range of $75-80 a barrel in 2024. OPEC decided to unwind its announced 2.2 million barrels per day of production cuts on a monthly basis, beginning April 2025. Oil prices had slumped to $60 per barrel in April. Global oil demand is muted at present. Global oil demand is projected to slow from 990,000 barrels per day (bpd) in the first quarter of 2025 to 650,000 bpd for the remainder of the year. Harshraj Aggarwal, analyst at Yes Securities, and Sumit Ritolia, senior analyst at Kpler, a shipping-focused data analytics firm, were quoted.

title: El S&P 500 se acerca a un máximo histórico por la expectativa de un alto el fuego entre Israel e Irán
content: Los mercados reaccionaron positivamente tras el anuncio del cese de hostilidades en Medio Oriente. El S&P 500 avanzó cerca de 1% y se ubica a menos de 1.1% de su récord previo.
resumen: El S&P 500 se acerca a un máximo histórico por la expectativa de un alto el fuego entre Israel e Irán. Los mercados reaccionaron positivamente tras el anuncio del cese de hostilidades en Medio Oriente. El S&P 500 avanzó cerca de 1% y se ubica a menos de 1.1% de su récord previo. El anuncio de un alto el fuego en Medio Oriente realizado por el presidente estadounidense Donald Trump alivió la preocupación por una posible interrupción en el suministro de petróleo del Golfo, lo que provocó una caída de más de 5% en los precios del crudo. Esto afectó a las acciones del sector energético, mientras que los sectores financiero y tecnológico lideraron las ganancias dentro del S&P 500. El índice S&P 500, que agrupa a las 500 empresas más grandes y representativas de Estados Unidos, se acerca a su máximo histórico impulsado por la expectativa de una tregua entre Israel e Irán, así como por los comentarios del presidente de la Reserva Federal, Jerome Powell, sobre la política monetaria. Jerome Powell afirmó ante el Congreso que la economía de EE.UU. se mantiene "sólida", aunque reconoció que los aranceles podrían elevar los precios y afectar la actividad económica. La agencia Reuters informó que las aerolíneas también se beneficiaron del descenso en los precios del petróleo. American Airlines subió 4% y Alaska Air Group avanzó 3.6%. En contraste, los valores del sector defensa, como Lockheed Martin y RTX Corp, retrocedieron 2.6% y 3.2%, respectivamente. En paralelo, los inversionistas analizaron las declaraciones de Jerome Powell ante el Congreso, donde reiteró que la Fed mantendrá una postura prudente antes de considerar nuevos recortes de tasas, en medio de la incertidumbre generada por los aranceles comerciales. Otros funcionarios de la Fed, como Raphael Bostic y Beth Hammack, coincidieron en que no es necesario reducir las tasas en el corto plazo. A las 12:50 pm, el promedio industrial Dow Jones subía 1.14%, el S&P 500 avanzaba 1.16% y el Nasdaq ganaba 1.53%. A pesar de la cautela de la Fed, el mercado continúa anticipando al menos dos recortes de 25 puntos básicos hacia fin de año, con el primero proyectado para septiembre. En Lima, la bolsa local reportaba una pérdida de 0.23 en su índice General, así como en su índice S&P/BVL Lima 25 en 0.64%.

title: El mundo se enfrenta a la situación “más compleja” en décadas, dice el Foro Económico Mundial
content: El mundo se enfrenta a la situación geopolítica “más compleja” vista en décadas- declaró a la AFP el director del Foro Económico Mundial ...
resumen:
El mundo se enfrenta a la situación “más compleja” en décadas, dice el Foro Económico Mundial.

En junio, el Banco Mundial redujo su pronóstico de crecimiento mundial para 2025 del 2,7 por ciento al 2,3 por ciento, siguiendo una reducción similar por parte del Fondo Monetario Internacional.

El Foro Económico Mundial sostendrá una reunión poco después de la participación de Estados Unidos en el conflicto entre Irán e Israel y sigue a meses en los que la economía mundial se ha visto golpeada por una guerra arancelaria lanzada por el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump.

El mundo se enfrenta a la situación geopolítica “más compleja” vista en décadas, declaró a la AFP el director del Foro Económico Mundial (FEM), advirtiendo que las turbulencias estaban “impactando el crecimiento global”.

El presidente y director ejecutivo del WEF, Borge Brende, dijo: “Es el contexto geopolítico y geoeconómico más complejo que hemos visto en décadas”, antes de una reunión del foro multilateral en la ciudad de Tianjin, en el norte de China.

Brende advirtió: “Si no logramos reactivar el crecimiento, lamentablemente podemos asistir a una década de menor crecimiento”.

Funcionarios, incluido el primer ministro de Singapur, Lawrence Wong, asistirán a la reunión del FEM de esta semana en la ciudad portuaria de Tianjin, conocida coloquialmente como el “Davos de verano”.

Brende dijo a AFP que todavía era demasiado pronto para predecir el impacto de los severos aranceles de Trump.

Brende dijo: “Es demasiado pronto para decir en qué terminarán estos aranceles porque las negociaciones aún están en curso”.

Brende dijo: “Creo que el jurado aún no ha emitido su dictamen, pero la globalización tradicional que vimos ahora se ha transformado en un sistema diferente”.

Brende dijo: “Este es un nuevo capítulo… especialmente porque el comercio fue el motor del crecimiento”.

El Sr. Brende también advirtió que el creciente conflicto podría tener un “impacto muy negativo” en el crecimiento global.

La reunión del FEM en Tianjin se produce en un momento incierto para la economía china, que ha atravesado años de crisis en el sector inmobiliario y un lento gasto interno.

Brende afirmó: “China realmente importa”, añadiendo que espera que el país represente casi el 30 por ciento del crecimiento mundial en 2025.

Brende dijo: “China está orientando su economía más hacia el comercio digital, hacia los servicios y también abriéndose ahora a un mayor consumo interno, algo que es importante”.

Desde finales de 2024, los funcionarios de Beijing han revelado una serie de medidas agresivas, incluidos recortes de tasas clave y cancelaciones de restricciones a la compra de viviendas.

Muchos economistas siguen siendo escépticos respecto de que la economía china pueda alcanzar el objetivo oficial de crecimiento del gobierno para 2025 de alrededor del 5 por ciento.

Beijing está mirando a tecnologías emergentes como la inteligencia artificial (IA) como posibles fuentes de crecimiento futuro.

Brende declaró a la AFP: “En el pasado, el comercio fue el motor del crecimiento, pero no se puede descartar que las nuevas tecnologías, incluida la IA, puedan… quizás reemplazar el importante papel que tuvo el comercio”.

Brende dijo que si bien el comercio seguirá siendo “muy importante”, las tecnologías disruptivas pueden brindar el impulso de productividad necesario para “evitar una década de crecimiento lento”.

El 24 de junio, los asistentes se apresuraron en una cavernosa sala de conferencias en Tianjin antes de las conversaciones con un grupo de oradores, entre ellos el ex primer ministro británico Tony Blair.

Se espera que el primer ministro chino, Li Qiang, pronuncie un discurso inaugural el 25 de junio.

title: Inflación ‘frena’ en primera quincena de junio
content: La inflación general en México disminuyó ligeramente a principios de junio, según un informe publicado el martes, ya que los inversionistas esperan que el Banco de México (Banxico), el banco central, ...
resumen: La inflación general en México disminuyó ligeramente a principios de junio. La inflación en la primera quincena de junio se desaceleró al 4.51 por ciento, en línea con la estimación mediana de los economistas en una encuesta de Bloomberg y por debajo del 4.62 por ciento del dato anterior. La cifra subyacente, que excluye artículos volátiles como alimentos y combustibles, subió al 4.20 por ciento desde el 4.15 por ciento de la lectura anterior, ubicándose ligeramente por encima del 4.16 por ciento estimado en la encuesta. Banxico implementó reducciones de medio punto porcentual en las tasas de interés en las últimas tres reuniones. Jonathan Heath afirmó que el banco haría bien en considerar una pausa antes de señalar que las autoridades probablemente procederían con un recorte de 50 puntos básicos. Los analistas también predijeron que la inflación para finales de año se desaceleraría al 3.9 por ciento y que la tasa de interés de fin de año de Banxico se establecería en el 7.5 por ciento. Bloomberg Economics estimó que el banco podría, por precaución, recortar la tasa de interés clave para préstamos en solo 25 puntos básicos. La tasa de referencia se encuentra actualmente en el 8.5 por ciento. La gobernadora del banco central, Victoria Rodríguez, insistió a principios de junio que, cuando se le preguntó sobre un aumento repentino de la inflación en mayo, el banco no solo tuvo en cuenta un dato específico. Banxico tiene como objetivo la inflación en el 3 por ciento, con una variación de un punto porcentual. El magro crecimiento económico, estimado en un 0.1 por ciento para este año, también ha sido considerado por la junta de gobierno como un factor que probablemente contribuirá a enfriar la inflación. El gobierno de México también se prepara para el inicio de una revisión del Tratado comercial que tiene con Estados Unidos y Canadá (T-MEC).

title: Asian pulse trade resilient amid Trump tariffs and geopolitical tensions
content: Amid trade tensions, India and Bangladesh are emerging as growth markets, while China turns to alternative suppliers to maintain pulse imports.
resumen:
Amid trade tensions, India and Bangladesh are emerging as pulse growth markets while China turns to alternative suppliers for imports. Pulses like peas, lentils, and chickpeas are now central to Asia’s food security and innovation agenda. The Asian pulse trade has remained remarkably resilient, despite tariff tensions triggered by US President Donald Trump’s administration and the China-Canada trade war.

The USA plays a relatively minor role in global pulse trade, exporting an estimated 1.2 to 1.5m tonnes annually—far behind Canada and Australia, which exported over 5 million and 4 million tonnes respectively in 2024, according to Rabobank. US tariffs are expected to have limited impact on the pulse trade.

Canada and Australia are expected to remain the top pulse exporters, accounting for 24% and 18% of global exports respectively. Russia’s share has risen to 13%. India dominates the pulse imports market at 32%, followed by China at 11%, and Bangladesh and Pakistan at 6% each.

Total Canadian pulse supply is expected to see only a slight year-on-year dip, but exports have declined more significantly amid strained trade relations with US and China. India’s growing appetite for peas since 2024 has led to a resurgence in trade volumes, with Canadian imports rising from 1.2 million tonnes in 2024 to 2 million tonnes between April 2024 and February 2025. The imposition of tariffs (100% in China’s case) has not completely derailed Canada’s exports to Asia. China has diversified its sourcing, turning to Russia and Kazakhstan, while Canada has seen new opportunities open up in South Asia.

The EU is grappling with new challenges. A 50% import duty on Russian and Belarusian peas, alongside sluggish domestic output and potential competition with China for Ukrainian supply, has put its self-sufficiency under strain.

Trump’s use of tariffs extended beyond simple economic leverage – the tariffs are wielded as strategic tools to influence foreign policy, domestic industry protection, and international negotiations. China’s decision to hit certain Canadian imports with tariffs were the result of diplomatic tensions linked to the 2018 Meng Wanzhou case.

Industry watchers will be paying close attention to whether India’s appetite for Canadian pulses holds, and whether other Asian markets continue to grow into stable long-term buyers.

Brende dijo a AFP que aún es demasiado pronto para predecir el impacto de los aranceles de Trump “porque las negociaciones aún están en curso”.

Brende afirmó que la globalización tradicional se ha convertido en un sistema diferente y advirtió que el conflicto arancelario podría tener un “impacto muy negativo” en el crecimiento mundial.

La reunión del WEF en Tianjin coincide con una coyuntura incierta para la economía china, afectada por varios años de crisis del sector inmobiliario y por el débil consumo interno.

Brende dijo esperar que China represente casi el 30% del crecimiento mundial este año.

Brende dijo que China está orientando su economía hacia el comercio digital, hacia los servicios y también se está abriendo para aumentar el consumo interno.

La administración china ha tomado medidas agresivas, como recortar las principales tasas de interés o poner fin a las restricciones a la compra de viviendas.

Muchos economistas dudan de que la economía china pueda alcanzar este año un 5% de crecimiento, el objetivo oficial del gobierno.

China está buscando desarrollar la inteligencia artificial como fuente de crecimiento futuro.

Brende dijo a AFP que las nuevas tecnologías pueden proporcionar el impulso de productividad necesario para “evitar una década de crecimiento lento”.

title: Pressure to Seal Trump Trade Deals Ramps Up With Two Weeks to Go
content: Two weeks from President Donald Trump’s self-imposed deadline to reach deals with the US’s major trading partners, some of the most-watched talks aimed at clinching agreements to avoid higher tariffs ...
resumen:
Two weeks from President Donald Trump’s self-imposed deadline to reach deals with the US’s major trading partners, some of the most-watched talks aimed at clinching agreements to avoid higher tariffs are struggling to get over the finish line.

As of July 9, exporting nations without a bilateral accord in place will face Trump’s so-called “Liberation Day” tariffs that are much higher than the current baseline 10% level applied to most countries.

Only the UK has secured something on paper, though that pact kept the 10% so-called reciprocal rate in place and left unresolved one of Britain’s pain points — 25% steel duties.

China has a fragile truce with the US that extends into mid-August to give time for negotiations to play out.

The administration will extend the tariff pause for those it considers to be negotiating in good faith.

For dozens of other countries, Trump plans to “set the tariff rate unilaterally in ‘take it or leave it’ deals.”

Court challenges to Trump’s legal authority for tariffs have provided an added element of uncertainty for companies.

European Union: The best-case scenario remains an EU-US agreement on principles that would allow the negotiations to continue beyond the early July deadline. Trump threatened to give up and impose unilateral tariffs. The EU will assess any end-result and at that stage decide what level of asymmetry — if any — it’s willing to accept or whether it will push ahead with countermeasures to correct any imbalances.

India: Trade officials from India and the US are still keen to clinch an interim deal before the deadline, but the two sides appear to be digging in their heels on some key issues, particularly on agricultural goods. The US is seeking access to India’s markets for its genetically modified crops, a request India has denied, while New Delhi wants an exemption to the reciprocal tariffs as well as sectoral duties. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi missed an opportunity to advance the trade deal with Trump when the US leader left the Group of Seven meeting in Canada earlier than planned last week.

Vietnam: Communist Party chief To Lam is set to lead a delegation of officials and business executives to the US, aiming to meet with Trump and clinch additional deals with US firms to help finalize an agreement. The nation has offered to boost purchases of American products from Boeing airplanes to agricultural goods to get a deal. Negotiators are close to a framework agreement under which Vietnam is pushing for tariffs in the range of 20% to 25%.

Japan: US auto tariffs appear to be the key barrier to a deal between Washington and Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba’s government, which is bracing for talks to drag on. Trump and Ishiba failed to reach an agreement at the Group of Seven leaders’ summit in Canada, despite holding three prior calls to discuss the tariffs. Opposition leader Yoshihiko Noda said after a meeting with Ishiba that the US is most concerned about the auto trade deficit and that no consensus has been reached. Both sides are now trying to schedule the next round of high-level trade talks. The US is set to raise tariffs on Japan to 24%, on top of existing duties of 25% on cars and 50% on steel and aluminum.

South Korea: South Korea has yet to make meaningful progress in trade negotiations. New Trade Minister Yeo Han-koo met with US officials in Washington on June 23, aiming to secure exemptions from tariffs, including those already imposed on cars and steel. This comes after a planned meeting between President Lee Jae Myung and Trump at the G-7 summit was called off at the last minute as Trump left the event early amid rising tensions in the Middle East. South Korea faces the risk of a 25% tariff, further squeezing its export-dependent industries already strained by the sectoral duties.

Thailand: Thailand, which has been threatened with a 36% tariff, began its delayed talks with the US last week. Permanent Secretary for Commerce Vuttikrai Leewiraphan said last Wednesday that Thailand’s proposals are good and stand a chance to bring down the tariff to the 10% baseline. The official proposal was submitted to Washington last week and detailed negotiations are underway, the finance minister said Tuesday. The US was Thailand’s largest export market last year, accounting for nearly one-fifth of the country’s total outbound shipments.

Malaysia: Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said that Malaysia’s negotiations with the US have been going well after officials met with US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick in Washington. Anwar said the imposition of the US tariffs was a “significant challenge” and added that about 60% of semiconductor products from Malaysia was exported to the US alone. Malaysia is seeking to reduce the US tariffs to below 10% for sectors critical to both economies. Both sides have agreed to finalize the talks before the tariff reprieve expires, Malaysia’s trade ministry said this week.

Switzerland: The European nation, also facing among the highest tariff rates of US allies, sketched a compromise around easing market access for some agricultural products, with Economy Minister Guy Parmelin saying he aimed to reach an agreement by early July. The US Treasury added Switzerland to its list of countries monitored for foreign exchange practices earlier this month. Trump’s erratic trade policies contributed to the Swiss central bank cutting policy rates by 25 basis points last week after a surge of the franc.

Canada: The US’s northern neighbor is seeking to make a deal by mid-July, according to Prime Minister Mark Carney who met Trump on the sidelines of the G-7 meeting. There are still differences between the two nations, according to the US president. Canada is preparing to increase tariffs next month on steel and aluminum — currently at 25% — if talks stall.

Mexico: Mexico and the US were earlier this month nearing a deal that would remove Trump’s 50% tariffs on steel imports up to a certain cap. President Claudia Sheinbaum expected to meet with Trump soon after their planned encounter was canceled when he departed early from a G-7 summit in Canada. A formal start to the review of the USMCA — the free trade agreement between Canada, US and Mexico — is expected to begin later this year.

title: Confianza de los consumidores en Estados Unidos se deteriora en junio
content: El índice que evalúa esta confianza publicado por la asociación profesional Conference Board cayó de 98,4 puntos en mayo a 93 en junio.
resumen:
La confianza de los consumidores en Estados Unidos se deterioró nuevamente en junio después de un repunte en mayo, en medio de preocupaciones por el impacto de los aranceles impuestos por el presidente Donald Trump, según un barómetro publicado este martes 24 de junio.

El índice que evalúa esta confianza publicado por la asociación profesional Conference Board cayó de 98,4 puntos en mayo a 93 en junio, una diferencia de 5,4 puntos.

Los analistas esperaban en cambio una ligera mejora, según el consenso publicado por MarketWatch.

La disminución observada en junio “borra casi la mitad de las fuertes ganancias” del mes anterior, señala la economista del Conference Board Stephanie Guichard, citada en el comunicado.

“Los aranceles [implementados por el gobierno de Trump] siguen estando muy presentes en las mentes de los consumidores y asociados con preocupaciones sobre sus repercusiones negativas en la economía y los precios”, añade.

title: La Comunitat ya nota el 'efecto Trump' y las exportaciones a EE UU caen un 8% hasta abril
content: Las ventas de las empresas valencianas a China y a Argelia, que se recupera como mercado, experimentan importantes crecimientos ...
resumen: Las exportaciones valencianas a EE UU retrocedieron un 8,1% en los cuatro primeros meses del año, sumando 911 millones, mientras que las importaciones lo hicieron un 21,4%, con 609,5 millones, según la información que ha dado a conocer este lunes la Dirección Territorial de Comercio en Valencia, adscrita a la Secretaría de Estado de Comercio. En abril, las exportaciones descendieron un 18,1%, mientras que las importaciones lo hicieron un 33,4%. Para la Comunitat EE UU es el principal socio comercial fuera de la Unión Europea y, además, cuarto destino de las ventas exteriores de bienes y quinto proveedor. En 2023, las empresas valencianas exportaron productos por valor de 2.850 millones, con aparatos y material eléctrico, cerámica, calzado, agroalimentación y componentes del automóvil ocupando los primeros lugares. Más de 8.500 empresas de la Comunitat tienen relaciones comerciales con este país, y fueron cerca de 4.300 las que realizaron ventas en 2024. Hay otras 150 compañías implantadas en el mercado americano. El retroceso en las relaciones comerciales con Estados Unidos representa el 7,2% del total de las exportaciones de la Comunitat. Las empresas valencianas elevaron sus ventas a China en un 39,2%, hasta los 237 millones, y a Argelia, con ventas por valor de 127 millones hasta abril. También hay incrementos con Letonia (51,2%), Rusia (19,6%) o Chile (38,8%), mientras que en el lado negativo se sitúan socios tradicionales como Italia, con una caída del 12% en exportaciones. La Comunitat suma 12.575 millones en exportaciones hasta abril, un 3% menos, mientras que las importaciones sumaron 12.402 millones. La región representa el 9,8% de las ventas españolas al exterior. En los cuatro primeros meses de este 2025, alimentación y bebidas, semimanufacturas no químicas y bienes de equipo representan los tres principales sectores exportadores, aunque sólo alimentación crece (un 10,3%). El descenso más llamativo se da en el sector de la automoción, con una bajada del 28,6%, hasta los 1.215 millones. En España, las exportaciones a EE UU bajaron en abril un 13,8% respecto al mismo mes del año anterior. España únicamente exportó productos por 1.367,3 millones a EE UU e importó productos por un total de 2.621 millones. Las exportaciones a Alemania (-12%), Francia (-11,5%) e Italia (-10,5%) también se han resentido. El comercio con la UE cae un 9,9% respecto a abril del año pasado. Las exportaciones a China aumentaron un 20,4%.

title: Daniel Herrero, CEO de Prestige-Auto: “En la industria automotriz actual no hay lugar para vagos ni para 12% de ausentismo”
content: El flamante presidente de la empresa que se hizo cargo de la operación comercial e industrial de Mercedes-Benz Argentina, habló de las oportunidades que tienen las terminales locales y de la necesidad ...
resumen:
Daniel Herrero, CEO de Prestige-Auto, dijo que en la industria automotriz actual no hay lugar para vagos ni para 12% de ausentismo.
Prestige-Auto comenzó a controlar totalmente la operación comercial e industrial de Mercedes-Benz Argentina.
Se presentaron dos nuevos modelos importados a Argentina desde Europa: las dos versiones de la nueva Mercedes-Benz Vito, Tourer y Furgón Mixto, y la nueva generación del sedán coupé Mercedes-Benz CLA.
También se presentó la app Mercedes Me.
Herrero fue CEO de Toyota Argentina por más de 10 años.
El nuevo Mercedes-Benz Vito se presentó en dos versiones, Tourer en configuración 9+1 y Furgón Mixto, importado de España.
Herrero es defensor del servicio.
En Prestige hay un segmento de nicho, que son los autos de lujo, y un segmento de producción, Sprinter.
Se buscará expandirse a Latinoamérica, con sistemas de conversiones y operación de postproducción.
Se ha pedido volver a exportar a Estados Unidos.
Se atenderán destinos que son complicados para Alemania, como Costa Rica y Nigeria.
Para Herrero, el rol del sindicalismo es clave en el cambio de paradigma de la industria automotriz actual.
No hay ninguna restricción para fabricar el Sprinter eléctrico en Argentina después de 2030, pero la inversión tiene que salir de la filial local.
Herrero tiene una relación excelente con Smata y Ricardo Pignanelli.
Herrero le dijo a Pignanelli que vagos y chorros en la industria automotriz actual no tienen lugar.
Un auto convencional tiene 2.000 partes móviles, un auto eléctrico 80.
La industria automotriz da 500.000 o 600.000 puestos de trabajo, y ahorra 12.000 millones de dólares.

title: Trump anuncia el fin de la guerra entre Irán e Israel; Teherán niega que exista un acuerdo
content: Irán lanzó nuevas oleadas de misiles hacia territorio israelí desde el amanecer, a pesar del anuncio sobre un “alto al fuego total”.
resumen: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, anunció el lunes un acuerdo de «alto al fuego» total entre Israel e Irán. El cese al fuego sería un proceso gradual de 24 horas que comenzaría alrededor de las 04:00 GMT del martes. Primero, Irán pondría fin unilateralmente a todas las operaciones, e Israel haría lo propio 12 horas después. Trump dijo que ambas partes aceptaron permanecer «pacíficas y respetuosas» durante cada fase del proceso. El ministro iraní de Relaciones Exteriores, Abás Araqchi, contradijo a Trump y negó que exista tal acuerdo, aunque se mostró abierto a cesar las hostilidades si Israel detiene sus ataques. En la madrugada del martes Teherán vivió una nueva serie de bombardeos. El conflicto inició el pasado 13 de junio, cuando Israel lanzó un ataque aéreo contra aproximadamente 100 objetivos en Irán. Irán respondió lanzando más de 100 drones y misiles hacia Israel. Estados Unidos atacó directamente algunas bases nucleares de Irán. El conflicto dejó cientos de personas fallecidas. El lunes 23 de junio, Irán atacó la base militar estadounidense de Al Udeid, en Catar. Los ataques entre ambas naciones dejaron más de 450 muertos y más de 3,500 heridos. Los Guardianes de la Revolución, el ejército ideológico de Irán, prometieron que Estados Unidos lamentaría cualquier nuevo ataque contra su territorio. El economista hondureño Julio Raudales dijo que el alto al fuego representa una pausa para llegar a «arreglos de paz». El experto en temas internacionales Omar Andrés García Calderón manifestó que espera que el acuerdo no sea simplemente un reacomodo de estrategias militares. Graco Pérez, experto en derecho internacional, apuntó que el cese al fuego es beneficioso, aunque podría ser quebrantado por los grupos armados que financia Irán, como los hutíes, Hizbulá o Hamás.
